TALK.START.PARA: —In Budget Paper No. 3, Portfolio Program Estimates 1989-90, the Attorney-General's portfolio includes subprogram 2.6, Marriage and Family Services. The subprogram's objective is stated as:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide for the solemnisation of marriage and to facilitate the present and future maintenance and stability of marital and family relationships and reduce trauma associated with breakdown in these relationships.

Honourable members will have noted in these appropriations a small but inadequate increase in overall funding in this area of the portfolio. Given that in every Budget since I became a member of parliament in 1984 this area of preventative social work has been underfunded, for the last few years I have made a point of drawing the House's attention to the need to review the poor level of support we allocate to marriage and family preparation and counselling. I usually remind honourable members that most marriages collapse due to external pressures such as work patterns and mortgage rates combined with a neglect of the marriage relationship due to inadequate life skills, an inadequacy increasingly evident in our society. I usually draw the attention of honourable members to just how effective the work of marriage and family educators and counsellors is for the couple involved and for the community which benefits from healthy marriages and stable families. I do not think there is any argument about that.

I usually point out also the massive imbalance in government resource allocation to post-family breakdown dysfunction when compared to the relatively insignificant resource allocation towards preventing family breakdown. Honourable members need only compare the combined Family Court and social security allocations for divorce and its consequences with the pittance allocated in their appropriations to those counsellors and educators who have shown that they can keep families together and healthy at a great saving to society and to the great benefit of individuals, especially children involved. In this regard I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two short sets of figures put together by Dr Moira Eastman in her book Family: The Vital Factor, which shows an up to date comparison of funds allocated to prevention of family breakdown with costs of breakdown in the years 1984-85 and 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also note Dr Eastman's research which shows a net return of $20 to $30 for each $1 of an annual grant to guidance and counselling services in terms of individuals who do not end up on supporting parents benefits due to preventative support. I will repeat that, because it is worth listening to again: Dr Eastman's research shows a net return of $20 to $30 for each $1 of an annual grant to guidance and counselling services in terms of individuals who do not end up on supporting parents benefits due to preventative support-the thing that seems to be escaping the reasoning of those who allocate government funds in this area. Needless to say, each of those reminders needs to be issued in this House once again today.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, however, I wish to draw the attention of the chamber to salient and relevant comments made by the Director of the Australian Institute of Family Studies, Dr Don Edgar, in the August edition of the journal Family Matters. I relate Dr Edgar's comments to the provision of marriage education and counselling services. Dr Edgar argues as follows:

More services for families should be aimed at prevention available early on in the process of family difficulties, rather than only being targeted at those who have gone so far down the track they are in real crisis.

Dr Edgar calls for a move from a top-down model of family services to a more sensitive model which focuses on family resources, advice when asked for, family information access and family enhancement skills-all very important areas. He bases his call on the Institute's findings that many of those in need of help do not know where or how to find it and/or stoically refuse to seek help from formal family support services. Dr Edgar argues:

If we cultivated a community value of using resources made accessible to all families, of expecting advice when a problem emerges rather than a rescue from disaster, a real partnership of family and formal support might emerge and a real strengthening of family life result.

Dr Edgar's focus and prudent priorities should be, but are not, shared by the Government, unfortunately. I heartily endorse his comments. I note, however, that these appropriations suggest that the Government is, as yet, unwilling to go down the path suggested by Dr Edgar who is, of course, the Director of a government-sponsored organisation. I also note the following comments made by Dr Edgar on the need for more research into these matters:

If policy makers really want the best for families, they should seek more research information on actual family aspirations, the actual ways in which families of different types and at different stages of the family cycle manage to cope and function on the resources they have, and to support and prevent damage to the fabric of family life.

Dr Edgar is right again. It strikes me as indicative of the Government's neglect of such research and an integrated family policy focus that the Institute of Family Studies has been dumped by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) into the social security portfolio. That dumping occurred after the Department of Community Services and Health was offered the Institute but indicated that it was not interested. That needs some explaining by the Minister. I take this opportunity to ask the Attorney-General to explain the forced move of the Institute from his portfolio, a move which occurred again without consultation with the Institute. I also take this opportunity to ask him to clarify the future of the marriage and family services subprogram, given the rationalisation of the function and responsibility under way in this Department.

In conclusion, I return to my main concern. The Government should be doing more to support and promote preventative programs in marriage and family education and counselling. The appropriations for these programs before us today are totally inadequate, especially given the current pressures on families of having both parents at work to survive high interest rates which, of course, we all know about it. They are short-sighted and imprudent. I suggest that they need to be reviewed over the next 12 months to be the cornerstone, hopefully in what might be called the world's greatest family policy statement, which is what the Government really needs to bring down if it is to be fair dinkum-if I may use that term-on child poverty, welfare dependence, school retention rates, drug abuse, family savings levels and the many policy challenges we face as a result of the neglect of the family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, when speaking on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department, I spoke primarily about the National Crime Authority (NCA). Today I will continue on that theme. As I said last night, organised crime and organised corruption know no boundaries-they are both interstate and international in their operation. The National Crime Authority is one of the great successes of this Government. Its role should be enhanced and its future enlarged. I believe very firmly that one of the problems we now face is a lack of action by State governments in assisting and enlarging the role of the National Crime Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Because people were scared and frightened of the royal commission style powers granted to the National Crime Authority and because this Parliament had concerns about the wide-ranging powers created by its legislation, an intergovernmental committee was established which severely limits the capacity of the National Crime Authority to go into investigative areas without a specific reference from that intergovernmental body. Yet we know, from all the available evidence, that there is great corruption emanating from the States, both in governmental and in corporate areas. The South Australian State Government, under Mr Bannon, recognised the problems of that State and was prepared to fund, with assistance from the Commonwealth, a National Crime Authority office in South Australia.

When the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct first hit the public media I was one of the very few people in this country who criticised that report. The criticisms were founded on the simple basis that the people being asked to repair the corruption in Queensland were the very people responsible for the corruption. Members of the Queensland section of the National Party of Australia, who have had their hands in the till of corruption for the last 14 years, were being given the responsibility to institute electoral and corruption reform. The National Party was given no directions, guidelines or specific references as to how it was to operate. The people who have had their fingers in the bickie tin of corruption for 14-odd years have now failed to institute electoral reform, and today newspapers report that Ahern is now backing away from the fundamental plank of instituting an anti-corruption body within Queensland. Frankly, no-one suspected that the National Party, that corrupt political party of Australian politics, would have done anything about it. It indicates to me the need for a National Crime Authority body to be established in every State of Australia.

It is unarguable that every State requires a body which is national in its approach to organised crime and corruption. The filth and scandal of corruption that exists in Queensland does not stop at the border. It is a nonsense to think somehow that the influence of the Queensland National Party suddenly stops at the border with the Northern Territory or New South Wales. That is another area in which I have made public criticism of the Fitzgerald inquiry-it stopped at the border. If one reads the Fitzgerald report one even wonders whether there is a drug problem in Queensland. That is why the NCA needs that resource. That is why the NCA should be enlarged in its scope and in its power to transcend State borders.

I believe also that the restrictions placed upon the NCA by the legislation-that is, the requirements for the State Attorneys-General to grant a specific reference to the National Crime Authority before it can undertake a particular inquiry using its royal commission powers-should be limited. If we are seriously to get into the heart and soul of organised crime that body needs to have a bit more power, a bit more strength and to have some of the State Attorneys-General controls removed. I do not think this will happen quickly or readily.

Frankly I do not see many State governments which would like an independent national crime authority body set up in their States. If we suggested to members of the Queensland National Party or to the Federal National Party that we should have a NCA body in Queensland, we could imagine the gulps and the gasps which would occur, as those people thought of their beloved leader Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen as being one of the targets. Those people would fight a battle a million miles off to ensure that that beloved leader was untouched. Yet without such a body people like Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen may well escape the net and they may well escape the fate that they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is Burke?
—Dowding?
—Are you talking about Dowding?

—I said all States. I do not name anyone else. Again, I stress: all opposition members, all States. It is unarguable that the stench of all corruption lies in all States; not just Queensland; not just New South Wales; not just Victoria-every State. SPEECH.PARA: I listened with interest to the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and I find myself in agreement with much of what he said. Yet here we have a member of the Opposition who, on the social services side, is looking for a $1 billion cut in Commonwealth expenditure and who is apparently supporting a taxation proposal for split incomes which will cost an enormous amount of money or a two-rate flat tax policy which will cost $2.3 billion in revenue. If we are looking at total cuts on the Opposition's stated policies today of about $4 billion to $5 billion, how can one then expand services as the honourable gentleman has suggested in this chamber? It ill becomes any Opposition member to come in here and to criticise the Government's Budget on that one line alone. Stop to think about it! That is on top of $1 billion in cuts announced by the Opposition. It does not take into account the inflation indexed proposals floating around the heavens of this chamber on which one day we may get answers.

Members of the Opposition who come in here and say, `Look, we can isolate the problems in societal terms and we can isolate the problems in government expenditure terms'-which I can agree with-are really making very shallow calls. I would much prefer to see the honourable member for Macquarie put a dollar sign on the Opposition's budgetary proposals, to lay such proposals on the table where those calls then have some validity, where I can believe that he means what he says rather than using this chamber as a forum for presenting his personal quirks. We all know that nothing occurs in government unless there is a dollar sign attached to it and the money comes out of some appropriation.

Last night I mentioned my great pleasure in the funding of the Office of the Narcotics Control Board computer system in Thailand and in the Philippines. I spoke very briefly on the national crime survey. Honourable members are well aware that the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority pointed out that one of the great problems we face in determining policies to tackle the major drug problem is the lack of statistical data, the lack of material as to what is actually occurring on the streets: the price of drugs, the quality of drugs and the source of drugs. This is one of the great initiatives that I believe the Government is undertaking to assist this Parliament and the organised groups who are fighting this battle to find that necessary material.

The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who has just spoken, apparently could not have heard what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to say yesterday about new principles. The honourable member did not talk about Halfpenny or Bjelke-Petersen. This is a new dimension. Apparently those opposite operate under the old dimension. They have not heard about the new one which was referred to yesterday at Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Trade Practices Commission has been allotted an extra $700,000 in relation to its activities. The Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, Professor Baxt, has stated:

We are very disappointed that we have not been given funds for the new work that the Commission has been asked to do and is now fully involved in, including telecommunications, the overseas cargo shipping work, transport generally and the new areas of de-regulation . . . We have not been given any specific funds in relation to that. We are still discussing this with Finance, we're hoping that we can persuade them to give us money outside the traditional budgetary formulations.

On many occasions the Trade Practices Commission has to use all of its resources for one job all around Australia, and these days, with the pilots dispute, it is difficult for it to carry out its work. Imagine the onus that is placed on the Trade Practices Commission to get results.

This area of the law has now been in vogue in Australia, I guess, for 20 years. It is gradually gathering some practitioners and some legal precedent which will be enormously important in the conduct of commerce in this nation. There is no way that this can be done unless the Trade Practices Commission is appropriately funded. Under a fully integrated and widely discussed privatisation program there will be a very great need for a properly staffed and funded Trade Practices Commission. This is quite clearly not the case at present and we, in government, would absolutely ensure competition in the market place by making sure that the Commission has adequate resources.

The second point I wish to address is the Australian Securities Commission, the legislation for which is still subject to challenge and, in part, not proclaimed. But despite that, there has been an allocation of $15.7m in the current year. Just to put that into perspective, currently the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) gets $3.5m with the States contributing the same amount. So, $15.7, or nearly double what the NCSC is getting, has been allocated to an operation that is not functioning and whose legislation is subject to legal challenge and, except for a small area, is not proclaimed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it doing with the money?

—It is making magnificent arrangements in various places in Sydney. Negotiations are being entered into with the States to try to set up the Securities Commission. A letter which fell off a back of a truck indicates that one of the 36 faceless men who took a very dim view of this outcome had the audacity to criticise the Commonwealth takeover. He has followed it up. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who is a well known frequenter of Randwick, does not welsh on a bet. All the boys involved got a job. All the people down the track who advocated the Commonwealth takeover of company law are now the chairmen of every committee to do with the new Australian Securities Commission. One thing about the Australian Labor Party (ALP) is that it always pays its debts.
—Except in Tasmania.

—Well, I do not know. A job will turn up somewhere down there as well. The members of the cheer squad are right at home in their jobs. Every one of them has a job in company law. In this area we are finding a number of curious little deals. The ALP cannot help itself. A deal is the thing it loves in every respect. The Attorney-General is an amiable fellow. He waltzed down to the Victorians and said, `What about some sort of an inside deal for you guys? We will take over the CAC. You break the line, and we'll take you over'. The Victorians, in a greatly cynical and expedient move on their part, said, `We'll hand over to you the CAC of Victoria and the funds that go with it-and you have to take all the staff as part of the deal-and we will pass some enabling legislation which would make a High Court challenge a bit dodgy'. But the Attorney-General said, `No, we will turn that one down'. He is a New South Wales member and he really wanted to go to Sydney. According to a letter I have here--
—From whom?
—It is from a member of the Committee, a Mr Beerworth. He is one of the 36 faceless men. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen the correspondence with Mr Bowen which you released and agree that Mr Bowen's ``challenge and no money'' approach-
which is the approach he has taken in New South Wales-

is both cynical and improper, particularly having regard to an earlier approach of his that the Commonwealth wanted the States to challenge because of the need properly to discover for the good of the community the limits of the Commonwealth's power.

That is, in the corporate area. That was the challenge. We have heard it in the House on many occasions. The Government says that the States should put up and challenge. But when New South Wales, for instance, does put up and challenge the Government says, `Drop the challenge. We'll do a deal'. Every constitutional lawyer-particularly the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown)-would know that the challenge currently before the High Court of Australia is extraordinarily questionable. I have no doubt that the High Court will agree to certain parts of the argument, but I have very grave doubts about its agreeing to 100 per cent of it. There is a need for this matter to be before the High Court and for a decision to be made.

The Constitutions of all the States in Australia very frequently refer to good government. Good government requires long term thinking. While I remain of the view that the Commonwealth will probably win with a substantial percentage of the High Court judgment, I do not believe that the States will go home empty handed. As a consequence of those proposals the High Court's action in this matter is very critical to all concerned.

I return to the main play. In the current year, we propose to spend $15.7m to establish this Commission. We are attempting to deal with the States in terms of taking over their Commissions and various things by saying, `If you challenge you'll get no money. If you drop the challenge we'll give you some money'. The budget projection for the next year is $65m. Even the appointed Chairman of the new Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell, in his first interview said, in summary, that what he was about was bringing good management to the securities industry of Australia. How are we going to do that? We are going to give it an adequate database based on new computers. Whacko! That will do big things for company law. He did not say that, instead of having a cooperative scheme in which all the States could discuss the matter and in which we knew where the money would go, what the States were prepared to negotiate and what positions they held-and instead of the threats of High Court challenges concerning the money-he would wipe that to one side and say to the States, `We'll give you all these wonderful things but it really boils down to new computers and so forth.

Before my time expires I wish to say one thing: in the time ahead there will be an enormous amount of work for company accountants and lawyers. There will be enormous legal costs as the corporations in this nation are required to drag them through the areas of registration in which they are currently involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the observations made last night by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). He complained formally about the methods employed to choke off the supply of information to people. He referred specifically to the Freedom of Information Act. I am able to cite a couple of examples to support his contention that the Act is being used by unscrupulous departments to prevent members of the Parliament and members of the public gaining access to documentation.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable members in this Parliament would be aware that I had reason, with legal advice and the assistance of some honourable members, to challenge the legality of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) conducting, as compulsory, the 1988-89 household expenditure survey. Indeed, the strength of legal opinion on our side was such that the matter was quite protracted. In the end, the Australian Bureau of Statistics even agreed, because of doubts as to the legality of the survey, not to prosecute more than 200 households that refused to be part of that survey.

Last year, because of my view that the Australian Commissioner of Taxation was responsible for delving into people's lives, via the household expenditure survey, I asked the ABS for details of those people who had suggested questions for the Australian Labor Party's 1984 household expenditure survey. I was advised that if I paid in excess of $11,000 that information would be made available to me. I was at the United Nations at the time this good news came through. I must admit that I thought that $11,000 was just too much. It might be regarded almost as a stamp allowance in the eyes of members of the Labor Party, but it was too much for me to be forking out of my own pocket.

I did not have the advantage of being able to compare this cost and I have never uttered a word about it in the form of a complaint. But earlier this year I wrote to the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman asking for stipulated documentation relating to the household expenditure survey. I also wrote to the Australian Bureau of Statistics seeking much the same information. There were some differences because the Attorney-General's Department had also been involved. I received a notification from the ABS to the effect that it did not see that any public interest was involved and the only way it would give me the information would be upon the production of a 25 per cent down payment on an account of at least $1,500.

TALK.START.PARA: —No public interest in a public survey?

—No public interest in a public survey. This demonstrates the sickness and the illness which pervade government departments of this day and age. I finally got a response from the Ombudsman. His account was a bit like a foursquare store. He had judged that the cost of providing almost identical documentation would be $600. So there was the ABS trying to strangle me by applying a charge of $1,500 and the Ombudsman applying a charge of $600. The Ombudsman then ruled that because of the huge public interest in the survey at least half of that cost could be justifiably waived. This is what is going on out there. Government departments are obviously closing ranks to strangle the public out and to strangle the members of the Parliament out.
—A conspiracy of silence.

—They are the words of the honourable member for Menzies. I had not got to that stage yet, but I will give it more thought. The effect it is having is to prevent people from being informed. I spoke in this chamber last night about the national health survey, which the ABS is lauding in medical journals as having the support of the Australian Medical Association (AMA). When I contacted the AMA at the end of last week after seeing the claims of support, the AMA informed me that its support was given on the condition that it be conducted as a voluntary survey. People are to be subjected to many questions about how many times they go to the doctor, clean their teeth and the like. Women are being asked whether they have an intra-uterine device fitted and about their contraceptive practices. On seeing all this, the AMA said that it was not going to have anything to do with a survey of this type unless it was voluntary. The ABS has this tremendous capacity to attract the crabs and draw attention to itself. I went to the office of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and said that I would like to see this questionnaire. His office contacted the ABS and an officer in the ABS who was not that senior told the honourable member's office that members of parliament are not going to see the questionnaire until the survey is completed at the end of next year. We have freedom of information, yet 44,000 Australians are going to be subjected to this questionnaire and we, the members of the Parliament, are not allowed to see the questions the public is going to be asked. Not to be rash, we gave the ABS another chance. The shadow Treasurer's office then made a formal application to the Acting Statistician, Mr McLennan, asking for the questionnaire again. The answer came back, `No, not to be given out'.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman-and I congratulate you on your recent elevation-what kind of country is this? Who is running Australia when the members of the Parliament who seek documentation and information are being strangled off by fees that only the Halfpennys of this world could afford to meet and are being prevented from seeing questionnaires that 44,000 Australians are going to be subjected to? The Freedom of Information Act was enacted in good faith by a Liberal government-with both a big `L' and a small `l'-so that people could be informed, but the monetary approach is now being used to prevent people gaining access to the documentation.

I also wrote to the Attorney-General's Department asking for the same documentation. I received a reply only today. The letter is dated 4 September. It says that it is not in the public interest that I be given the documentation without charge and that it will be advising me in due course as to the fees that will be applied. When it came to the 1988-89 household expenditure survey, I suggest that the ABS and the Attorney-General's Department worked hand in glove together to protect the Bureau from its failure to comply with the requirements of this Parliament that a survey be tabled before its commencement. It does the Attorney-General's Department no credit to make a judgment that this information will not be available on the grounds of public interest. A lot of public interest is involved in these surveys. When people are threatened with the force of the law and when they can face fines of $100 a day for not complying with a direction of the Australian Statistician, it is people's rights that come to the top; not the interests of government departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday when we were considering these estimates the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) criticised me for drawing attention to the shortcomings in the way in which the Freedom of Information Act is being administered by the present Government, saying, as he did in substance, that it had nothing to do with this debate. I simply remind the honourable member that the estimates inform us of what are described as the major achievements of the Attorney-General's Department. At page 16 of the estimates one of the major achievements of the Department is held out as being `an improvement in the processing of FOI requests'. Without going on about it at length I say simply that if that is one of the major achievements I would hate to see some of the shortcomings.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen how the present Government is allowing the use of the Freedom of Information Act to fall into a complete and disgraceful shambles. It has raised every technical objection it can and continues raising technical objections to prevent the proper use of the Act. It imposes excessive charges on people, including members of parliament, to deter them from using the Freedom of Information Act. When we succeed in getting over that obstacle race what we often get by way of documents released under the Freedom of Information Act is similar to those that I showed the Committee last night. I again draw the Committee's attention to one masterpiece from which it would appear that we were living in Romania or the Soviet Union. That is an example of freedom of information under the Australian Labor Party. That is what we get for a lot of money. I think it is time that the Government woke up to itself about this Act and either proposed to repeal it or started, for the first time, to administer it honestly and efficiently in the true spirit that was the basis of the Act when the former Government introduced it.

I simply leave the matter there and plead with the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), to go back to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). It is a matter of regret-I presume there is some good reason for the Attorney-General not being here when his estimates are being debated-that he is not here. I urge the Minister to take that point back to the Attorney-General.

While he is doing that I urge him to take back to him my concern about another area of the Department, the Special Investigations Unit. An appropriation of $3,263,000 in the estimates is to be used by the Special Investigations Unit to investigate people who may be charged under the War Crimes Act, or people who, to quote the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-this was at a time before he discovered yesterday the new principle that people are innocent until they are proven guilty-will be charged under the War Crimes Act, and appear to be guilty. That is the way the Prime Minister put it, at a time even before the Bill was passed, let alone before people were charged or convicted. That was in the days pre-Halfpenny. People were not innocent until they were proven guilty. In those days when the Government was in full flight with the War Crimes Bill, according to the Prime Minister people were guilty before the Bill had been passed and before anyone had been charged or convicted.

I come back to the operations of the Special Investigations Unit and simply make the point that the Government cannot come in here and ask for $3,263,000 for the Unit without a substantial explanation being given to this Committee as to how that money is being spent and when we can expect some results. It is not that we are pleading with the Government to charge someone. We are simply saying that it started this matter. It put this slur over some ethnic communities in Australia. The Prime Minister was running around saying that they were guilty anyway, and where is the result? I do not know of a case where so much money has been spent on chasing what seems to be now so few people with so obviously little result. Indeed, the only result of the activities of the Special Investigations Unit that I can see is that its principal investigator has been charged with some criminal offences. That is the only result.

It must be unique in the history of investigating or law enforcement bodies that the only person associated with them who is up on a charge is their principal investigator. The Government cannot allow this shambles to go on. We are simply saying that it has to give an explanation. It has to tell us how the job is going and when we can reasonably expect some results. It began with 500 people on the list. The number went down to 400, 300, 200 and 100. I gather that now it is down to a mere handful. We want to know when we will see some tangible results. If we do not see any tangible results soon, we will ask the Government to address its mind to whether this Unit should continue in existence and whether we should have this War Crimes Act anyway. That point has not been reached, and I say that in fairness, but it will be reached if the Government goes on spending money and fumbling around in the way in which it is in this area without any tangible results.

Having said that, I want to move briefly to a few other matters. One of them relates to the staff in the Attorney-General's Department who, in my view, have been treated in a very shabby way. They have worked under difficult circumstances and, particularly in recent years, under salary scales which are quite inconsistent with the quality and significance of the work that they do. Indeed, many of them could earn twice or three times their salaries outside the government service. It is about time that the Government faced up to this and set up a sensible career structure for lawyers in the Department and remunerated them adequately in recompense for the high quality of the work that they do.

Before anyone gets agitated and runs away like Senator Walsh and says that I am advocating a vast increase in government expenditure, let me say that I am not advocating that at all. I believe that there are areas within the Attorney-General's Department which probably deserve a lower priority than the priority the Government seems to give to them, but in the important work there should certainly be a better career and salary structure because the people involved deserve it and need it. If it is not done soon, the Government will find a continuation of this haemorrhaging, this migration, this evacuation from the Department of highly qualified and skilled people.

It should be placed on record that not only do people in the Department who work in many of these areas perform very well indeed with the very high quality of work, but also they do so in many cases at salaries much lower than they are entitled to and much lower than they could obtain in the private profession.

It is a fact that we have now had a duopoly for three decades, it is a fact that there has been some featherbedding for our domestic airlines, and it is a fact that when we go into deregulation next year the airlines will have to undertake a great deal of restructuring if they are to stay in business. TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of matters I would like to raise this morning about the estimates of the Department of Transport and Communications. SPEECH.PARA: Rather than just a maintenance of funding, Radio Australia desperately needs an injection of funds to upgrade its facilities throughout Australia and possibly overseas. At present the possibility of a transmitter in Thailand is being negotiated. There are numerous aspects to all this. At one stage Radio Australia felt that it was in a desperate plight. In my travels through the South Pacific last year there was jamming of the Radio Australia signal by, dare I say, the French. At appropriate times when Radio Australia was broadcasting to the South Pacific the reception was not strong enough. When a tape was played to me of a Radio Australia broadcast in Western Samoa I could hardly decipher the words because of the jamming involved. Because of the poor reception people could not listen to Radio Australia.

I will quote from the parliamentary report tabled earlier this year. It summarises quite succinctly the concerns and the recommendations which we put forward and which I would like to raise again in this House today. Page 100 of the report entitled Australia's Relations with the South Pacific the Committee states:

5.47 The Committee was disturbed at other evidence put before it that the effectiveness of Radio Australia was threatened due to declining transmitter effectiveness, as well as increased competition in the region from other broadcasters. The run-down in facilities is disgraceful. Radio Australia has experienced funding cuts over a number of years, and up-grading of transmitter sites serving the Pacific is long over due. The Shepparton (Victoria) site, in particular requires extensive modernisation and up-grading.

5.48 The Committee is aware that as part of the Australian Government's review of national broadcasting policy, the future of Radio Australia is under consideration. The Committee finds it hard to see why an inquiry such as this is required. The options appear clear-to provide Radio Australia with sufficient funding under the current arrangement, retaining Radio Australia's links with the ABC; or if this Government is genuine about the value such a service provides, providing Radio Australia with sufficient funds to exist as a separate body. In addition to the above two options, the Committee understands that the inquiry is also looking at the options of merging it with other bodies; retaining Radio Australia in its current form but instituting revised funding and consultative arrangements; or establishing Radio Australia as an independent statutory body. One suggestion made was for funding for Radio Australia to be allocated via the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Committee totally rejects this option, believing it is important that the independence of Radio Australia new broadcast be maintained. More importantly, Radio Australia must be seen to be separate from the Australian Government's foreign affairs bureaucracy, despite the occasional difficulties this might cause Australian diplomatic efforts in the region. For Pacific listeners, the independence of the service being presented must not be compromised. The Committee rejects the idea of any government department determining the content of Radio Australia broadcasts.

5.49 The Committee's overriding concern is that Radio Australia obtain sufficient funds to perform its functions successfully. The Committee heard in evidence that Radio Australia relied `very much on the facilities of the ABC to ensure that we survive. There is no way that we could be a totally independent operation' and if that situation continues then continued association with the ABC with an increase in funding would seem the most preferable outcome.
That is the recommendation I support. The Committee goes on to say:

5.50 The Committee fully supports the continued existence of Radio Australia and commends the decision of Radio Australia in 1988 to reorder its regional target priorities to place the South-West/Central Pacific region as its first priority, and therefore to take an even more active role in the South Pacific. The Committee recommends that sufficient funds be allocated to up-dating Radio Australia transmitter facilities, particularly those used in targeting the Pacific region, and in up-grading the programs produced specifically for the region.

I echo that statement, which was put unanimously by the Committee. All the parties, including the independents but excepting Senator Brian Harradine, were represented on that Committee. I fully support those recommendations. I again ask whether the Government could possibly provide a further injection of funds for the upgrading of Radio Australia in the foreseeable future. It is a very important facility. It is used throughout the Pacific and South East Asia and indeed throughout the world, but in those two regions in particular because of their importance to Australia.

I will touch on another area of broadcasting and television and comment on the Government's television policy. It is no secret that I did not entirely agree with the Government's ownership policy when it was brought forward. I pushed for the 43 per cent policy, as it was known; that is, that a person or company could own only 43 per cent in a company with Melbourne or Sydney access. The Government thought otherwise and the ownership level is now at 60 per cent. As a result of that decision, there were buy-outs all over the place. Frank Lowy bought the Channel 10 Network, Bond bought the Channel 9 Network from Packer, et cetera. Eventually, we saw Skase buy the 7 Network. Another person who agreed with me, if I may say so, is the former Minister for Communications, the present Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy). We did not win that battle.

It is worth noting that Mr Lowy, because of his hastiness to get into the industry, has now lost a reported $280m. My concern is that we set certain hares running that need not have been running because in essence whilst logically the Government's policy is correct-there should not be much logical difference between owning 43 per cent, 60 per cent or 70 per cent-what occurred happened as a result of the Government announcement. When one looks at the matter logically now, there is no reason why people such as Bond or Skase need own all five or six stations around Australia.

I have always said-and Sir Frank Packer always said-that as long as a person owned Melbourne and Sydney networks it did not really matter. In an economic sense if a person owns networks in those two cities, he controls everything else. Practically the entire economic worth of the network lies in Melbourne and Sydney. If a program is not sold in one of those capital cities, it is not sold at all. Programs must be carried in both of those capital cities. If a person owns networks in both capital cities, the networks in other capital cities may as well not exist. Therefore I would suggest that Broadcom Australia Ltd in the Channel 10 saga will control the network because it will have a huge say. I still do not believe that the policy is totally correct. It is a little hard to go backwards now after we have let the genie out of the bottle. I hope Mr Skase and Mr Bond make a go of it. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the estimates of the Department of Transport and Communications I want to begin by talking very briefly about the pilots strike although I do not want that to be the burden of my remarks this morning. Just about every aspect of that dispute has been debated furiously around Australia. But one aspect of it that does not seem to have had a great deal of airing is the relationship between the individual pilots and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP), their so-called union. This is a relationship which in some cases is a happy and comfortable relationship but in other cases it is a relationship of strain and even of duress. The simple reality is that the AFAP has put the hard word on pilots and in the present circumstances those pilots who wish to return to work have it made clear to them implicitly or explicitly-it is probably implicitly-that if they return to work they are strikebreakers and their careers will suffer forever and a day because they are strikebreakers.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things I think the Government should do is to introduce right to work legislation of the kind that has been introduced around the United States. I think it exists in 40 States of the United States. This legislation guarantees employees, in this case including airline pilots, that if they defy the union, if they resign from the union, that union or any other similar association cannot harass them and, to take an extreme instance, cannot harass them out of work. Right to work legislation would give great comfort to those pilots who wish to return to work. Right to work legislation would be one very constructive way in which this matter could come to an early resolution.

I hope the Government will consider right to work legislation, will use a little imagination, perhaps will walk away from some of the more entrenched ideological positions that it has taken over the years in industrial relations and will realise that there is a commonsense solution to these sorts of problems. That legislation is one aspect of a commonsense solution that could apply to the present pilots strike and in future it could apply to a whole range of industrial disputes where union leaders and union bosses bully their employees into industrial action and where those employees very reluctantly have to suffer not only dire personal economic consequences but also from the ignominy of causing enormous inconvenience to the rest of the community.

The burden of my remarks today is about transport infrastructure in Australia and I will pick up on one aspect of that debate which I do not think has been given sufficient airing. We have heard a great deal about the problems of the waterfront and the need for those problems to be solved. That will be an important part of the new Peacock Government's program. We have heard a great deal about coastal shipping and, again, that is something the Peacock Government will be addressing after the election. Deregulation of airlines and improvement in airline facilities will be another important part of that new government's policies.

One sector of transport which is a forgotten sector is without doubt railways. In Australia railways are in as urgent need of restructuring, of reinvestment, of upgrading as is any other sector of our transport industries. The railways in Australia are currently in a state of crisis. Many politicians in Australia, State and Federal, are simply resigned to that crisis. It is estimated that in Victoria and New South Wales alone, the losses of their railway systems constitute a subsidy of about $2 billion per annum. This is an enormous loss. It is therefore an enormous drain on the community-a cross subsidy from the productive sector of the economy to the unproductive, loss making railways of those States.

I do not think we should be too pessimistic about railways because in the longer term efficient railways are something that we can achieve in Australia. There are a couple of bright hopes. There is the entrepreneurial proposition that a very fast train should be built. Whether we think that is likely to happen and whether we think it is likely that money will be made out of property speculation rather than out of the running of an efficient railway service is a matter for individual judgment. It is interesting to see that people are coming forward with that sort of entrepreneurial private enterprise proposition. One only need go to countries like France and Germany to see how these high speed trains can be so very effective. Enormous changes have also taken place in Australian National, the former Commonwealth railways. I think that body deserves to be congratulated on the way in which it has turned that which used to be a substantial loss-making operation into, at least on its freight side, an operation which makes a very small profit.

Railways in this country can be turned around in terms of freight operations. I do not think that is true of passenger services. Passenger services, in terms of becoming profitable, have very little hope. So far as passenger services are continued, they should be continued as a community service obligation, not as an economic proposition. But freight has very real prospects. One only has to look at the United States and Canada to see how extraordinarily profitable rail freight services can be. In both those countries the private sector has proved that it has done extraordinarily well out of running freight railways as has, in turn, the business community. Therefore the economy as a whole has done well out of being able to use those railways to good effect.

If we are to do that in Australia we have to be prepared to make very substantial changes. Initially we have to address overmanning and restrictive work practices in both our State railways and in Australian National, although that issue is being addressed in Australian National. I guess it is in some of the States as well. If we look at the comparative productivity figures in railways-for example if we take the number of tonnes of freight moved per freight employee-Australia is quite uncompetitive with countries like the United States and Canada. In the United States a little over four times as much freight per employee is moved and in Canada the figures are similar. That says something about the low level of productivity we have in this country. If we take the number of train kilometres per freight employee one would think we would do pretty well because our freight trains cover many kilometres. We are outgunned in this area not only by the United States and Canada-we are really and truly outgunned by them-but we are even outgunned, by that definition of productivity, by little Sweden. We would not have thought that Swedish railways covered big distances. Obviously, by comparison with Australia, they do not. In terms of train kilometres per freight employee, Sweden is substantially more productive than Australia. I do not want to encourage the Australian Labor Party too much when it comes to Sweden. V/Line admits that it could increase its productivity by about 30 per cent. One reason that productivity has been so poor over the years has been that railways are uncompetitive-it is a public monopoly-and they have been used as a job creation scheme and very little else. There has been union resistance to change and that has to come to an end.

It is worth noting that Booz-Allen and Hamilton in New South Wales has estimated that overmanning and restrictive work practices alone on the New South Wales railways are costing something like $110m per annum. I think that makes the point very clearly. We will not succeed unless we improve productivity on our railways. If we do, we have the very real prospect, following the example of Canada and the United States, of turning our freight railways into very profitable and important operations in terms of the revival of our economy.

We also need to address the issue of the interrelationship between the different railway systems. It is often said that one of the four or five great mistakes of Australian history is that in Australia we have five different railway systems and at least three different gauges. It is hard to do very much about the stupidity of the different gauges because that will require enormous capital investment. Mind you, if railways become profitable I think that will occur. But we ought to try to better integrate interstate freight movements around Australia, perhaps under the auspices of one organisation such as Australian National Railways, to ensure that those systems can be properly marketed and run. I do not have time to say a great deal more about this.

In conclusion, if we can make our interstate freight services efficient and have them coordinated by Australian National Railways, even if that involves a shareholding by the States in Australian National Railways, then we can develop a truly profitable railway freight sector in Australia which could lead to injections of private capital and, with a bit of luck over the years, real scope for the privatisation of our railways, turning them into an extraordinarily efficient and dynamic part of the Australian transport sector.

I drove on roads in Africa last year and anyone who thinks our roads are anything like the roads of Africa or Asia does not know what he is talking about. It is a very silly argument.

It was particularly pertinent that this letter came from Burradoo, because early this year the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) opened the Berrima bypass, a project worth more than $87m. This road is one of the best in Australia. The nonsense about our roads being on a par with African roads is about as silly as the claim that our roads are worse than they were some 10 years ago. People putting these arguments, and those in the Opposition supporting them, lose any credibility in the debate.

During the appropriation debate several members have spoken about roads, including the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks). Even the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) last night spent some time in this wide-ranging debate talking about roads. They have highlighted the tragic loss of life on Australian roads. No-one argues that it is indeed a tragic loss. The honourable member for Gilmore is far too intelligent to believe the nonsense he spoke in his speech the other day. I refer him to an editorial in yesterday's Canberra Times which, in a very intelligent way, indicates some of the causes of death on Australian roads. It actually dealt with some of the issues that the honourable member raised in his speech. There are many causes, including alcohol, speed and driving in a manner not consistent with prevailing road conditions, as the paper says. I always find it interesting that, when members of the Opposition talk about roads, they are more or less saying that if the Government would only put more money into roads we would have no road accidents. That is a silly argument, and they know that it is a silly argument. Road conditions are of course a contributing factor, but they are only one of many contributing factors, as is high speed. High speed in itself does not cause road deaths. Speed kills only when it is combined in the wrong proportions with youth-too often, unfortunately-with alcohol, with weariness, with ignorance or with bad weather.

I was also pleased to see that the Canberra Times yesterday raised the question of the damage heavy vehicles do to our road system. The honourable member for Gilmore knows-he reminds us frequently in this chamber-that heavy freight hurtles down the Hume Highway through the centre of Goulburn day and night. I believe that much of this freight should be transported by rail. I was very pleased that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) raised the question of rail, because it is the cheapest and most effective way of transporting freight, especially over long distances. Yet rail operators in this country are forced into an unfair situation. Even the levy that they are forced to pay on their fuel goes to subsidise their competitors, the road freighters. If the average person had to pay the full price of transporting goods by road, very little freight would go by road, yet in New South Wales we have a Liberal and National Party government that is closing down railways.

I agreed very much with what the honourable member for Mayo said about rail. We need an efficient rail system. As I have said, it is the most effective and cheapest way of transporting goods over long distances. I think that there is great potential there for interstate transport. I also support his comments that it should be coordinated. I have a disagreement with him: whereas he wants this all to happen in the private sector, I want it to happen in the government sector. Where a profit motive is involved, I do not see why that profit should not come to government and be returned to the taxpayers of Australia.

In the long term national economic interest both State and Federal governments should be putting more money into rail. If more freight is transported by rail and some of the trucks that are doing so much damage are taken off the roads, we would not have the constant cry for more money to go into the road system. The ordinary motorist driving a small car is not churning up our roads, it is the trucks carrying all that heavy freight-much of it should be carried by rail-that are churning up and destroying the road system in Australia.

It is particularly annoying that in the politically biased and totally dishonest campaign being conducted by motoring organisations, especially the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA), they never point out who does the real damage to our roads. I sincerely hope that in the forthcoming elections for the NRMA more responsible people will be put in charge of that organisation. The actions of the motoring organisations in advertising have been dishonest and misleading. I personally have no argument with their campaign for more money to be spent on roads, but I feel very strongly that their arguments should be accurate.

The increase in funds to the States and Territories for road projects continues this Hawke Labor Government's pledge to maintain road funding in real terms. It is clear evidence of the strong priority this Government gives to roads. As I say, a large proportion of this money will be spent on the national highway system and national arterial roads. One national arterial road has not been funded-a proposed road in my electorate called Caloola Pass-because, as we know, under the national arterial system it has to be recommended by the State Government. This road will link the highlands to the coast. It will complement the excellent work begun by the Port Kembla harbour task force in getting a grain terminal at Port Kembla, and helping Port Kembla reach its full potential as an export development port. But it will never reach that full potential without adequate infrastructure.

One of the first actions of the vicious Greiner Liberal Government was to stop work on the Maldon-Dumbarton rail link, which would have transported coal from the southern fields to Port Kembla. Instead the coal will be trundled through the Sydney suburban system to the dangerous and inadequate Illawarra system, leading to even more congestion. The Greiner Government should have gone ahead with the Maldon-Dumbarton rail link. Most importantly, the New South Wales Minister should have listed Caloola Pass as a priority for funding. The Federal Government would have funded it as a national arterial road. The only link on the southern part of Wollongong, Australia's seventh city, is the Macquarie Pass, which, frankly, is nothing better than a goat track. The first coal or wheat truck to use that road will be the last. It is very important that the New South Wales Government recommend Caloola Pass for priority funding under the national arterial roads system. I have the assurance of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) that, provided the road receives high priority, it will be funded by the Federal Government. In that way part of the transport infrastructure of this country can be made better for the benefit of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: We appreciate the fact-and we are thankful for small mercies-that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have seen fit to grant an extra $116m for roads this year. Let me say a few words about the conditions of roads in Australia. We were pleased that certain roads, particularly the Pacific Highway, were reclassified as national arterial roads. It is important that we come up with programs that will overcome the inadequacies of the road system. I was very pleased to see the New South Wales Government imposing a tax of 3c a litre on fuel--

We have to be big enough to acknowledge that there is a need for a railway between Alice Springs and Darwin. There is a need for a railway across the very north of Australia. I have said what I wanted to say. I would love to say a lot more about our road system and arterial roads. I could cite roads in my electorate that I am very concerned about. With the channelling of national roads into these areas and with present resources, they cannot meet the demand.

I conclude with this: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is still a worry. What has this Government done for the future of Sydney Airport? Has the environmental study been carried out? We see in the papers articles which state that it will cost twice as much. This Government is waiting for the election to be over, but God only knows what will happen as far as this great central airport is concerned. Will the Minister, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), or somebody else tell us exactly where we stand with the Sydney Airport? TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues on this side of the chamber in this committee stage debate in concentrating on the transport side of it. I congratulate the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), who has just completed his speech, on his excellent contribution. I also congratulate my colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) on his contribution, which highlighted some of the merits of rail. As has been pointed out by a number of speakers, rail has a very exciting future in this country. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) says that it is probably the cheapest and most efficient form of transport available to us if we can operate it properly. It certainly is a very efficient and cheap form of transport if it is operated profitably.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to the chamber today that probably the most efficient form of transport in this country is actually coastal shipping. The only reason why that does not happen at present is simply that we do not have an efficient coastal shipping service, nor an efficient waterfront. I want to speak briefly on both those subjects today in the 10 minutes that I have available to me.

Before I do that I just want to follow up on some of the comments made by the honourable member for Lyne, who spoke principally about roads, and just home in on the fact that, whilst the Government claims that this year it has had an increase in road funding of $120m, in actual fact that is an exaggeration; it is $116m. The increase in road funding of $116m is only a fraction of the extra taxes that motorists will be paying this year at the petrol bowser. Excises on fuel will increase by $482m through this financial year whilst the Government will be giving back to the motorists only $116m of that $482m in the form of funds for road improvements and maintenance.

So it is quite obvious that, despite the claims of this Government, the motorist is being ripped off yet again. Of course, today we have had the unfortunate experience of finding that, in the last 6 1/2 years of this Hawke Labor Government, road funding has been reduced by about 30 per cent in real terms. To give an idea of what effect that will have, I can talk about an area with which the honourable member for Throsby would be familiar-indeed, I am familiar with it in my electorate-that is, the Hume Highway. When the former Liberal-National Party coalition Government announced the Australian bicentennial road development fund back in 1981 or 1982, it stated that the by-pass around Goulburn would be completed by the year 1988 as part of our bicentennial celebrations and that the Cullerin Range deviation would be completed by 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without a rail easement, unfortunately.

—Without a rail easement, yes. Unfortunately, today work is just commencing on those bypasses and deviations, and we have a four- to five-year construction program ahead of us before that completion will occur.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we are experiencing these delays of five and six years is simply that the Government, over its period of office, has reduced road funding by some 30 per cent. It is also worth pointing out the comments made by the honourable member for Throsby that people on this side of the chamber have been intimating that, by improving our roads, we will, in some way or another, remove road fatalities. He was referring to an editorial in yesterday's Canberra Times. Unfortunately, road fatalities will not be removed completely as a consequence of improving our road infrastructure throughout this country. But the National Roads and Motorists Association, in its research, has found that, if we improve roads to a proper standard, we will reduce the incidence of accidents and fatal accidents by about 80 per cent-possibly by as much as 85 per cent. So there is a direct correlation between proper road funding and a reduction in road fatalities and injuries on our highways.

Last year, fatalities and injuries on the road system throughout Australia cost this country some $6 billion. That is a cost that we cannot afford to bear in the future. There is a very good, sound economic argument why we should increase road funding. The Liberal and National parties, in their policy, will be announcing a significant increase in road funding which will please many people in this country-indeed, even the harshest critics-and which will set us apart from the Australian Labor Party and give those 4.9 million members of the automobile associations around Australia a very good reason to vote for the Liberal and National parties whenever the next election is held.

I want now to turn to the waterfront and just briefly express my disappointment and outrage at the way in which this Government has stopped the Australian Wheat Board and the Grains Council of Australia from enabling the Aegean Dolphin-a ship that was to have unloaded grain at the Brisbane grain handling terminal recently-from using non-Waterside Workers Federation labour, as was the original plan. The Australian Wheat Board agreed with the Grains Council of Australia and the Brisbane grain handling terminal people that Waterside Workers Federation employees would not be used for the first time on the unloading of grain at the Brisbane grain terminal. The Government stepped in and said, `We cannot have this. The Waterside Workers Federation people are our mates. We cannot have them being cut out of a job'. So it heavied the Australian Wheat Board, particularly the Chairman of that Board, and forced it to renege on the agreement that it had with the Grains Council of Australia and to re-employ those Waterside Worker Federation people on the waterfront when that grain was being unloaded.

I was up there the other day looking at that very terminal and I was informed by the people who operate the terminal that the Waterside Workers Federation employees are absolutely and utterly unneeded for the tasks for which they are allegedly employed. Indeed, most of them sit around; some of them wash their cars; some of them read the newspapers; and some of them just lie about and sunbake; but none of them actually does anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some work very hard as well. Come down to Port Kembla some time.

—I can assure the honourable member that, in the case of the unloading of grain at the Brisbane grain terminal, as is the case throughout Australia at present, those people are not needed for this task. As a consequence, the Government is imposing an additional cost on grain growers throughout Australia of about $20m each and every year. I believe that that is outrageous, particularly when Australia is in urgent need of extra export income due to our current account deficit, which is reaching record high levels. So this Government is engaged in the business of propping up the trade union rorts that have gone on in the waterfront for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the Government's reaction to the report of the Inter-State Commission on reforms on the waterfront we will see further evidence of that. The Inter-State Commission's recommendations, whilst not perfect from my point of view, were certainly achievable and workable and would have delivered significant benefits to the Australian economy. Unfortunately, the Government reneged on the Inter-State Commission's recommendations. It has watered them down in key areas such as enterprise employment which would have given employers on the waterfront the opportunity to hire and fire people who work on the waterfront, which is currently denied them. The Government backed away from picking up that recommendation. It also backed away from compulsory stand-downs and compulsory redundancy recommendations by the Inter-State Commission, which it said in its report were part of the key aspects of its whole package of reform on the waterfront and that if the Government did not pick them up the whole package would fail.

Of course, this has not stopped the Government spending $150m of taxpayers' money on redundancy payments to waterside workers who will be leaving the waterfront over the next three years. Indeed, a 55-year-old waterfront worker with 30 years experience will pick up 247 weeks of redundancy pay, paid for by the taxpayer, which represents a considerable amount of money. A State Rail Authority worker made redundant in the reforms that have taken place recently in New South Wales would enjoy only 26 weeks of redundancy pay. But if one happens to be a mate of the trade unions or this Government, one picks up 247 weeks of redundancy pay through the package which the Government is putting forward. Many people leaving the waterfront are reaching or are over 60 and normally would be retiring anyway. This Government is giving them an additional bonus, which will be well in excess of $100,000, plus their superannuation, so they can have a more comfortable retirement. All that is being paid for by the Australian economy.

Each and every Australian will be hurt as incomes are reduced because of the inefficient work practices that have existed on our waterfront for many years and which are being maintained by the Government, despite a lot of rhetoric about the need for reform on the waterfront. The Government's Appropriation Bill does nothing to help roads, which are collapsing throughout Australia, or make our waterfront more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget provisions for road funding have left the entire community of Australia aghast. The gross increase of the paltry sum of $120m for the entire road system of Australia is shameful. I refer to some figures which, I think, spell out very clearly the Government's inappropriate determination of road funding. We must bear in mind that the Government boasts a Budget surplus and, at the same time, receives an enormous increase in tax take. I refer to fuel tax in particular. The Budget provides for an excise on fuel of no less than 23.152c a litre, which will yield the enormous and staggering figure of $5,645m. From that enormous sum, the estimated allocation for roads for the current financial year will be only $1,333.2m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is trying to con the motorists of this country into believing that there has been an adequate allocation of funding. The truth is that the total allocation, compared with the tax take, is nothing more than a con. This country's roads are falling to pieces. Tremendous efforts are being made by State government, particularly the Government of New South Wales which, as a recourse, has had to impose a further fuel tax to try to prevent the total collapse of the road system in New South Wales. The reason for this rests squarely on the shoulders of the Federal Government.

Wherever one travels currently one finds the road system in chaos because maintenance cannot keep pace with its deterioration. With the weather conditions that have been experienced in the past nine months or so, there has been tremendous damage to most roads throughout Australia, particularly on the east coast. The Pacific Highway is one glaring example. One can travel for hundreds of kilometres and observe the tremendous damage which has been caused; yet there has been no special allocation made from the enormous sum of $5,645m that the Federal Government will rake in from the fuel tax to try to alleviate the situation.

Nothing could rate as a higher priority need, because of its relationship to the productivity of normal business in this country, than the transport of goods from one part of the country to another, particularly in key areas where there is an export content; yet we find the additional sum of only $120m being provided in the current financial year. The situation is deplorable.

Turning to the other level of road responsibility, that of local government, most local government bodies are struggling to maintain their road system. Both in my electorate and that of my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) local governments have no alternative but to revert long sections of road to gravel because there are no funds for the maintenance or upgrading of sealed road surfaces. All the councils in my electorate face this dilemma. In particular, the council of the shire of Kyogle has an enormous length of both local and main roads within its boundaries. The rate levels are astronomical. The ratepayers cannot be expected to contribute additionally to the current rating in that shire. The same applies to the shire of Richmond River and to all the local government bodies throughout both the Richmond and Clarence valleys on the north coast of New South Wales. Those councils have appealed for additional funding. They have endeavoured, in a proper and meaningful way, to put forward a case for adequate funding to meet the very difficult circumstances confronting them; yet the Government turns its back on this particular aspect of the public need.

In the remaining time available, I just want to say that there are other very worrying issues in the transport and communications area. The current pilots strike is an enormous one. It is crippling most of Australia and certainly country areas, except where commuter air services continue to operate, are at a great disadvantage.

But the real issue for the whole of Australia is the debacle concerning Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and the provision of an additional runway. There is no way that air transport in this country can adequately serve the needs of both the internal sector and the enormous tourist industry, which is so dependent on international flights, unless the Government faces up to the responsibility of speeding up the construction of an additional runway at Sydney Airport. We find go-slow tactics in all the procedures that the Government has promised to undertake.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.

—The Minister says that is not right. If she is prepared to make a positive statement in this House about the environmental study and why it is taking so long, if she will give a positive date as to the completion of that study and when the first actions will be taken to get something moving on this third runway, then the public of Australia will be greatly relieved. SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the dilemma facing the television industry in Australia is of enormous proportion. The people who must be considered in it are the members of the public-the viewers, those who require television as part and parcel of their everyday life, and the advertisers and shareholders of the respective television companies. We have a mishmash of legislation which has created an enormous debacle. It may well be true that there has been some management ineptness in the television area. He says, `We are considering legislation; we may have some further legislation'. There is no definitive statement, no positive action. The industrial relations club, in trying to maintain a flawed system, is pursuing rhetoric which is designed to inhibit the return of airline operations to normal. In other words, in the sector of transport there is available to the Government an immediately applicable way by which it could boost the domestic surplus and stimulate productivity in the Australian economy. Sadly, it is not doing so. Of course, that is not the only recommendation. If we can save $3.2 billion a year, surely the Government should be doing something about it. Neither in the field of micro-economic reform nor in the elimination of unnecessary regulations is the Government doing anything except talk.

SPEECH.PARA: It is regrettable that as far as the road transport, rail transport, coastal shipping and waterfront handling sectors of our economy are concerned the Government has been long on rhetoric and very short on action. We are told that reform of the waterfront, coastal shipping and ports could provide 27 per cent of savings or between $800m and $1.1 billion, with a 20 per cent improvement in productivity, while cheaper international shipping could yield 15 per cent of the savings or $400m. TALK.START.PARA: —Last week in the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 I made reference to the Government's 30 or so training schemes which are, for the most part, useless.
