TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether he is aware of any recent information on how the level of taxation in Australia compares with that in other countries. If so, can he advise the House of the relevance this has for government outlays and proposals that have been put by some people in the community to tighten the stance on fiscal policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was provided with a copy of the latest report on revenue statistics of member countries by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) published in Paris late last week. The latest comparative statistics are for 1987 and show that Australia has the fourth lowest tax share to gross domestic product (GDP) of all 24 OECD countries. These statistics are well recognised as the most accurate measures available because they incorporate all additional levies, such as specific social security charges, indirect taxes, et cetera. The total tax share of GDP in Australia is 31.3 per cent. That figure compares with an OECD average of 38.8 per cent. There are only three countries lower than Australia: Japan with a tax share of 30.2 per cent, the United States of America with 30 per cent and Turkey with 24 per cent. All three countries are recognised as having a substantially lower provision of public services than does Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In other words, by international standards Australia is a low tax country or, more accurately, a very low tax country. For the information of the House I table the chart from the OECD publication. The same chart published in 1982-before this Government came to office-showed Australia to be the seventh lowest tax country of the OECD member states. In that intervening period Switzerland, Portugal and Spain have all moved above Australia in the international taxing league table. More recent comparisons are not available but, since the Commonwealth's tax share is lower this financial year than in either 1986-87 or 1987-88, we can be confident that the Federal Government has contributed to sustaining Australia's position as a low tax country since 1987.

The reason we are able to maintain that position-that is, to have Australia go from seventh lowest to fourth lowest tax country in the OECD-is that we have fiscal policy under control. When we came to office outlays were 30.1 per cent of GDP. This year they will be at 23.7 per cent. Excluding Medicare the ratio will actually be under 23 per cent. The Forward Estimates show that with the decisions already made outlays will track down to 22 per cent of GDP by 1992-93, as I have said on a number of occasions, to the average of the 1950s. It is this discipline over fiscal policy which will see Australia continue the progress it has made in slipping down the OECD tax table. Contrary to the myth perpetrated by the Opposition, Australia has an extremely well targeted and efficient welfare support system compared with the rest of the world. The countries which are below us have nothing like the safety net which we have.

There is a great contrast on fiscal policy between the Government and the Opposition. It is significant that since the Budget we have seen the Opposition shift its policy to endorse the Government's fiscal policy stance. As I pointed out a couple of days ago, the Opposition Leader now says that the $9.1m surplus brought down in the Budget is the right result. In his two major post-Budget speeches he has discarded his earlier commitment to tighten fiscal policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say additionally at the outset that the current airline dispute is a shambles and a national economic disaster. It has been exacerbated by the words and actions of the current Prime Minister, both by the words I have just used in his traducing and his playing of politics and, of course, by his own talk of compensation for the airlines which has done nothing to solve the dispute. What has occurred is that Ansett Airlines of Australia has moved away from the nonsense in which he was engaging. In principle, Ansett is now doing what the Opposition has advocated all along-entering into voluntary contracts with the pilots.

This dispute is the direct result of Labor's industrial relations system and the accord. The accord is doomed to failure, because it grants across the board wage increases irrespective of the needs of individuals and their employers and irrespective of productivity in the workplace. It hands down decisions on how much to pay people without having any means of knowing what they should be paid at the industry or enterprise level. It is inevitable that after years of pressure building up in such a rigid system many groups of employees and employers would want to settle wages and working conditions between themselves. Despite the failure of the Government's centralised system and despite the Prime Minister's politically inspired and inept exacerbation of the dispute, the shreds of a solution may now be emerging. Obviously, key elements of any solution are in the coalition's industrial relations policy.

Clearly, the Prime Minister's failure to solve the dispute within the Government's industrial relations system heralds the end of the centralised wage setting system and spells the death knell for the accord. The dispute would not have happened under the coalition's industrial relations policy. Let it be remembered that under our industrial relations system the pilots and the airlines would have faced a choice: either they remained in the industrial relations system with effective enforcement provisions as outlined in the Bill introduced into the Senate by the coalition; or they negotiated a voluntary agreement, either on an individual basis or through a union, which was binding on both parties. If, for instance, the pilots and the airlines remained in our industrial relations system, wages would be set according to the circumstances in the industry, including productivity and competitiveness-that is, the Industrial Relations Commission would not be handing down wage decisions unrelated to the individual's workplace, as occurs under the accord. On the other hand, if the pilots and airlines choose to negotiate a voluntary agreement, any such agreement on wages and conditions would by necessity be based on productivity as well as taking proper account of other factors affecting the viability of the industry. In short, the wages and conditions would have to be affordable. The discipline ensuring that both parties reach an affordable outcome is the force of competition facing the industry. If they were to reach an unaffordable agreement the airlines would be forced out of business and the pilots would lose their jobs. To achieve a truly competitive airline industry, the coalition has always maintained, freeing up the labour market must go hand in hand with real competition within the industry.

I indicate now on behalf of the Opposition that when in government we will act to ensure maximum competition in the domestic air industry and will ensure that there are no artificial barriers to entry, such as through restrictions on the use of domestic terminals. Furthermore, we will give serious considerations to permitting foreign airlines to operate domestic air services in Australia after the two-airline agreement expires. It would create a whole new series of pressures on both the airlines and the airlines' employees to behave in a totally different way. In short, a wage breakout by the airline pilots would not take place in the decentralised system advocated by the coalition.

For days, even weeks, the coalition has called upon both parties to enter into negotiations. Now at last Ansett Airlines is offering to negotiate voluntary agreements with the pilots. Moreover-surprise, surprise!-there is even talk of an enterprise based union for Ansett pilots. So it is clear that Ansett Airlines is grasping at elements of the coalition's industrial relations policy to find a way out of this dispute. It is clear that the only way out of the dispute is for negotiations between the airlines and the pilots, either individually or through the union. What a shambles we have had-a dispute caused by the Government's industrial relations policy inflamed by the Prime Minister's intervention and prolonged by the Government's talk of compensation to the airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! Put a bit of oomph into it.

Negotiations with the pilots: is it not interesting? The Prime Minister constantly says that the Opposition is on the side of the pilots. We are not. We condemn this dispute and have throughout. We do not side with the pilots. So frequently in this place does the current Prime Minister raise this question in an increasingly agitated manner that it begs the question `Whose side is he on?'. He is certainly not on the people's side, nor on Australia's side. His behaviour has been erratic, his interventions ill judged and inflamed and, more than any other person, he is responsible for the exacerbation of the dispute and the damage that it is causing our nation. The irony of it all is that now he is trapped into supporting a form of settlement which will place a bomb in the basement of the outmoded system from which he has so long profited and to which he has for so long been committed.

The accord has institutionalised inflation at about 7 per cent, created a rigidity within the labour market which is choking this country, created a very restless work force, and failed to deliver productivity improvements. The outmoded system is now seen for what it is-a brake on the productive capacity of the country. At last, by the settlement process now being mooted, it has been seen to fail, as has the accord throughout. The system and the accord have failed. It is the coalition's policy which is providing the way forward. It was to the coalition's policy that the Government should have turned from the beginning.

If he were here the Prime Minister would rant and rave, agitate and perhaps salivate, seeking to condemn the Opposition, for there have been but two constants in his behaviour in this dispute-to traduce the pilots and to traduce the Opposition. He did it again today. Playing politics, he has completely overlooked the broad national good. He has not given a damn if this strike ruins hundreds and thousands of people. Oh no; he wanted to declare war on the pilots. Even when I said that, in the circumstances, bringing in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) to seek to break the dispute was a worthwhile measure to allow a movement of people, he sought to play politics with that-not one cubit of concern about the broad national good. Had he still been President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he would have been appalled had a Prime Minister behaved as he has done throughout this dispute. To hell with negotiation, to hell with settlement and to hell with Australia has been the standard of his behaviour. Some Prime Minister! Some failure! He has been on the wrong foot from the start and even at this stage there is total confusion in the community as to whether compensation is on or off. As late as midday today, when the program The World Today went to air, in answer to a question he said:
Let's get it quite clear-
here is a conflict in terms!-

on this question of compensation. There is no suggestion that there will be any consideration of compensation for losses suffered by the airlines. What the hell does that mean? If it is not payment to the airlines, what is it? If it is not a form of compensation, what is it? The confusion is abounding throughout the community. That point has continued the strike unquestionably. At root, this Prime Minister is not the national leader. He is a fix-it man, one who normally stitches up a deal. Now, glory be, after all this time there are negotiations. The fix-it man has flunked it. The only people to suffer are the people of this country.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I refer to consistency of treatment. The Minister consistently interrupted the Leader of the Opposition during his speech and to claim that we on this side of the House were in some way being unfair is quite unfair.
—There is no point of order. The Chair makes an assessment as to whether the behaviour in the chamber is appropriate to the debate.

—This dispute began almost eight or nine months ago when there were the first soundings from the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. First, there was the 24-hour ambush dispute in February of this year, which was condoned by the Opposition. It said not one word. Then there was preparation such as would be given to a complex military manoeuvre for how the pilots would arrange the dispute, how they would comply with periods when they may be out of work, when there may be a dispute, what actions they would take and how they would prepare for it. It was a carefully planned, almost military type, attack on the economy and people of this nation. There was not a word from the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: When the pilots had negotiations with the airlines on each occasion they made it abundantly clear that they were not interested in negotiation in the usual definition of the word. They were interested in putting a gun to the head of the country by demanding that the airlines give them a 30 per cent increase in salary. They would accept nothing less.

They then moved to the next stage of their activity, which was to start to soften up the airlines by working from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., at the same time saying that they did not want to disrupt the economy or the travelling public. The airlines responded by giving the pilots 24 hours to indicate whether they were prepared to carry out their obligations under their award. They did not give that undertaking. Some 24 hours later the pilots resigned en masse. As I understand it, many of those resignation forms were prepared in advance, undated, and then collected and dated by other people and lodged together. It was a carefully planned exercise by the people involved in an attempt to wreak maximum damage on their industry and this country, while at the same time escaping their obligations as employees.

Throughout that exercise the Opposition said a range of things. The Leader of the Opposition said that the Government was right and should be supported in the course it followed. On the other hand, other members of the Opposition said it should be left to the pilots and the airlines to negotiate what they wanted, that they should sort it out among themselves. The Leader of the Opposition said something similar again later during the dispute. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), said that the pilots could not get what they wanted under the Opposition system. Opposition members continued to present conflicting views on what should be done.

I make it very clear that from the Government's point of view if the airlines had yielded to a demand for a 30 per cent increase in salaries from the pilots that would have been followed by a host of other organisations and groups of employees across industries. The result of that would have been massive wage inflation of the sort the Opposition put this country through in 1980-81; there would be a wage explosion, inflation and mass unemployment. In no way will this Government accede to those kinds of demands and allow that kind of wage breakout.

Some members of the Opposition said that it should be left to the pilots to sort it out themselves. Others said they should be able to get productivity gains. I say to those members of the Opposition who believe that the pilots should negotiate their own arrangements and leave it to the market to determine the matter and to get some productivity improvement that from discussions we had in recent days it is clear that there are 350, maybe 400, pilots too many. Someone might explain to me how, in a market with such an oversupply of pilots, a higher level of productivity would enable the market to give the pilots a 30 per cent increase in wages and salaries. That is a nonsense. But that effectively is what the Opposition is trying to present.

The fact is that what has been negotiated between the airlines and the pilots is new arrangements for each pilot and each airline. Those new arrangements include a considerable increase in effective, productive time of the pilot-hours at the stick, hours controlling aircraft. If the pilots want to work longer, they have the opportunity to earn overtime by engaging in longer hours of productive activity. What is happening here-the disruption, the damage that is being done-is the Opposition's policy in practice. The Leader of the Opposition referred to real competition in the industry and spoke of the two-airline agreement. The two-airline agreement is a product of the Opposition's creation. It is its agreement; it is its system; so it is very good of the Opposition at this stage to be trying to place on us responsibility for that arrangement.

I want to contrast what would happen under the Opposition's policy of letting the system rip, of letting the pilots have what they want, the damage that would follow, with what has happened under this Government. The Opposition is obsessed with denigration of the accord, obsessed with having a reduction in industrial disputation. It is obsessed with a whole system of consultation between industry, the trade union movement and government and it wants this free-for-all system that it has referred to. The damage which it would wreak on the economy-the unemployment, the inflation, the collapse in growth, the collapse in the economy-is to be contrasted with the increase of one and a half million new jobs in the last 6 1/2 years; the record low level of unemployment in this country over the past seven years; the record rate of business investment; the stability; the growth which is occurring because we have had industry, trade unions and government exercising restraint; a 14 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs over the last 6 1/2 years because there has been a joint commitment to improvement, to stability, to consultation and restraint in wage costs, a restraint in wage levels. The Opposition seeks to destroy that and to go back to a free-for-all policy that could have only one result-the destruction of the economy, the collapse of growth and the loss of jobs such as we saw under the previous Government in 1981-82.

If we turn to what is currently happening in the system, we see that the Leader of the Opposition asked why the Government had not fixed it. The industry is practising the Opposition policy but the Leader of the Opposition asked why the Government has not fixed it. Under the Opposition policy, there is no role for government. The honourable member for Bennelong wants pilots and employers to sort out their own arrangements. There is no role for governments at all. Under that policy, the responsibility for discussion is between the pilots and the airline concerned. The Opposition also asked why negotiations did not begin before. Negotiations and discussions between individual pilots and both airlines have been going on almost since the day of the first mass resignations. In this dispute, the Government has resisted demands for wage increases that would destroy the economy and hurt the people least able to defend themselves. We have sought to bring in additional aircraft from abroad. We have changed our policy in respect of international airlines operating in this country, enabling them to operate domestic services. We have utilised the services of the Royal Australian Air Force to provide some level of service-as I said previously, not sufficient or adequate but preferable to the damage that would be done to the economy and to this nation had the Government yielded to the pilots' demands as the Opposition has exhorted us to do. That is really what the Opposition has been about throughout this dispute.

Currently we have the provision of something like 13 per cent of normal air services. That does not help everybody but it enables the people most needing to move to travel by air. Some 16 international airlines are helping to move people on domestic services. I believe, with some optimism, that some of our own domestic aircraft will be back in service within a matter of days. Both airlines are bringing in foreign-registered aircraft to commence domestic services in this country. Both airlines have indicated that they have signed up qualified pilots with the endorsements that they need to operate their aircraft. The numbers have not yet been stated but, as I said, there is now a sign of optimism and the opportunity for both airlines to look to some resumption of services. That has been done at considerable inconvenience to people in this country.

Throughout this campaign by the pilots support, succour and encouragement has been given by the Opposition to the Pilots Federation. There is not a role for the Federation. Pilots have resigned but the Pilots Federation, the group that is controlling this whole operation, is in regular contact with the Opposition. It has been given support and encouragement by the Opposition. I do not need to assert that. Anybody who has read in Hansard the statements made in this Parliament over recent days or has listened to the statements of members of the Opposition can draw his own conclusion. It is abundantly clear that their comments, criticisms and statements, by their nature, are designed to give encouragement to the pilots and the actions they are undertaking.

We will not countenance that attack upon Australia or the Australian economy. It is a case of crocodile tears when the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) stands up here and asks questions about the damage being done to tourism and that evening is on the phone talking to the Federation: `How are you going? Have they got any of your side up? Has anybody cracked?'. The next morning those opposite say, `What a terrible lot of damage is being done to the tourism industry'. That is the utter hypocrisy of the Opposition.

This Government has no intention of yielding to the demands of the pilots. The negotiations now going on between the individual pilots and the airlines are matters for them to follow through. The airlines have given assurances to the Industrial Relations Commission and this Government that the terms of contracts will be within the guidelines of the national wage case. We will continue to try to improve the alternative and supplementary services that are currently available to minimise the disruption that is going on, but under no circumstances will this Government give in to the demands put upon the economy and the airlines by the Pilots Federation with the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What an ironic and irrelevant performance we have just had from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris). It is ironic that a man who was at some stage the Minister for Transport is in here defending the Government's performance in a transport dispute when he was moved from that portfolio because of his failure to accommodate the requirements of some of the more significant players. It is also irrelevant because, as Pamela Williams has reported in the Australian Financial Review on behalf of Mr Kelty on a number of occasions, the Minister for Industrial Relations is not part of the main game when it comes to industrial relations, and he certainly has not been part of the main game when it comes to this industrial dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: This dispute has been run by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and we should have the butcher and not the block in here today to explain the Government's position. But we should be grateful in one respect that we do not have the Prime Minister here. The Minister is going through the motions-the same old tired lines: `The Opposition is in bed with the pilots'. That is absolute rubbish. Everybody knows that we have consistently called on the pilots to go back to work. More relevant questions for the Minister and the Prime Minister are: who are they in bed with? Who do they spend most time on the telephone with? Who spends most time in their offices? Is it the employers or the employees? How many discussions has the Government had with Mr McCarthy and how does that stack up with the number of discussions the Prime Minister has had with Sir Peter Abeles, Mr Strong and others involved in the dispute?

The other part of the Government's big propaganda approach to the whole issue is that this is the coalition's fault. Let me give the Minister and the Government some news. They are in power. They have the treasury bench. They are running the so-called industrial relations policy of this country at the present time. This dispute is caused by the Government's policy. But, of course, it is not the Government's policy. The Prime Minister does not set the industrial relations policy of this country. It is not set by the Cabinet, and it is certainly not set by the Minister for Industrial Relations, who is at the table. All of us on this side of the House know who it is set by. It is set by Mr Kelty and Mr Crean.

It has been interesting in regard to this dispute to know who has been in the Prime Minister's office: as I said, not Mr McCarthy, but Mr Kelty has been in there. He is not a party to the dispute. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots is not part of the Australian Council of Trade Unions but Mr Kelty has been in the Prime Minister's office. He has been there in a big way. Why? Because the Government's actions in the whole dispute have been designed to prop up the accord and to prop up Mr Kelty.

Let us have a look at the facts of this dispute, which are clear and straightforward. The dispute was caused by the accord. That is simple and clear. It was caused by the Government's wages policy. It was inflamed by the Prime Minister. He rushed up to it, doused it with petrol, threw a match into it and walked away. He has been belligerent, he has been aggressive and he has made some incredibly stupid statements. The dispute has been prolonged by the compensation carrot that, as late as midday today, the Prime Minister was still waving around in the air. There has been no commitment to meaningful discussions while some people thought that compensation was on the agenda.

Nothing more than this dispute and the Prime Minister's actions reveal the inadequacy of the Government's policy, the inadequacy of its strategy and the inadequacy of the Prime Minister. The accord is a centralised system; it is rigid and inflexible. At the very outset it prevented the parties getting together to settle the dispute. The dispute would not have occurred had there been a more flexible decentralised wage system in this country-a system that the coalition has advocated for years.

This dispute would have been far less costly to the Australian people had the Prime Minister not been so stupid and aggressive. We see evidence of that here in this chamber today. Normally there is standing room only in the public galleries. Today they are virtually empty. Why? Because people cannot get here. The tourist industry is paying a price of $36m a day and the Prime Minister is not prepared to come to the chamber to justify and explain his attitudes and tell us what he will do to solve the dispute. The bottom line is that he is in power, he was keen to get in there and kick the pilots, he is the one who declared war, and he is the one who said that the pilots are only bus drivers. The Prime Minister learned to fly in seven hours. It is a wonder he is not out there captaining a 767. It is a wonder he is not at the stick himself. Where is he now? He is not prepared to debate the issue.

Another very interesting thing is the double standards of the Prime Minister-the workers' mate. He may not agree with the pilots or like what they are saying but he ought to be talking to them. This is the man who claims that he is interested in conciliation and consensus. Where is the conciliation and consensus in his approach to this dispute? Nowhere at all. The Government did not want a peaceful resolution to this dispute. It set out with three objectives: to break the pilots; to maintain the accord at any cost, no matter what the cost to the tourist industry or the average Australian; and to stop negotiations. The reality is that the Government has failed. It has not broken the pilots; the accord is dead-let me say that clearly and categorically-and the Government has not stopped negotiations. Otherwise, what are the airlines doing?

The reality is that the Government's approach was stupid, irresponsible and costly. The Prime Minister's motives in this whole issue are questionable, and one wonders whether the country is being run on a political agenda again. He talked about bringing in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). The RAAF arrived and carried 2 per cent of the normal passenger load. Then there was interlining, which accounted for 7 to 8 per cent. Then he said-and the man was obviously poorly briefed-that foreign pilots would be brought in. He did not know that there is a worldwide shortage of pilots and that that would not happen. The next thing was charters. What arrived? We have a dodgy airline from the United States of America, someone from the Middle East and an Ilyushin. If the Prime Minister wants to fly in an Ilyushin, I wish him luck.

The history of this dispute, which is also quite interesting, highlights the double standards in this matter. The pilots started with a work-to-rule. That was deplorable and it is not to their credit that they acted in this way. The full dispute started a couple of days after that on 23 August-two weeks ago. This dispute has been costing us millions of dollars a day and still there is no progress. The pilots' awards were cancelled within 24 hours. Within 24 hours the Government had acted against the pilots. Some of us remember the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF). It took this Government two years to do anything about that body. It all depends on one's priorities and Mr Kelty's attitude to these sorts of things.

All the Government has done, from the very beginning, is escalate this dispute. Even last week the Prime Minister was still insulting the pilots and calling them hypocrites. Again there was talk about compensation. If anything is designed to remove the resolve of the airlines to get together and start talking about a resolution of this dispute it is the suggestion of compensation. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proved so conclusively a few moments ago, the Prime Minister still does not know what he is going to do about compensation. It may not be a live issue, but it is certainly on the agenda. Compensation may not be given to the companies. But if it is given to the employees, surely it will benefit the companies.

We have seen a confused, chaotic approach to this dispute. The Prime Minister, in spite of what has been said by some of his Cabinet colleagues, still makes statements such as the one about compensation. I cannot believe that he does not understand the need to address this dispute more vigorously than he is at the present time. Apparently this dispute has cost the country $100m in August in terms of our balance of payments; the current estimate for September is $180m. Yet, the Prime Minister is not even in the chamber now and we have not seen a statement from him. Five thousand Australian men and women have been stood down. They are not on the Prime Minister's compensation list. Their families will not be able to ask the Prime Minister to help them pay the rent. Hotel occupancy rates throughout this country have dropped like a rock. What is the Prime Minister doing about that? Our international reputation continues to be damaged. We have damaged our reputation for the next decade as a tourist destination for visitors from countries like the United States of America, Japan, the United Kingdom and New Zealand. The work that has been done at great cost by this Government-and it frequently claims credit for this-and others in the tourist industry to promote tourism has been wasted.

The reality is that the Government should recognise that the Prime Minister has made an unholy and unmitigated mess of this dispute which is the result of the failure of the Government's accord and social wage policy. There is no credibility in the Government's policy or strategy on this whole issue. The Government should recognise that it owns an airline and that it is in a position to direct the management of that airline to do something-to talk to the pilots and to begin moving to resolve the dispute. It is within the power of the Government to act, but it will not do so because of political reasons. It is important that this Government understands that the accord is dead. The accord should be buried and Mr Kelty should be buried with it. The Government should act to end the suffering and cost and resolve this dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -This matter of public importance clearly indicates that the Opposition has decided to put itself forward as the advocate of the pilots. The Opposition claims that the present situation has been caused by the failure of the Government's industrial relations system to bring about a settlement of the pilots dispute. Let me go back a couple of days to 25 August when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) first made statements in relation to this dispute. He said, in an interview on AM on that day:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer/employee fight and look after the national interest. And the Government is correct.
On 25 August the Leader of the Opposition said that the Government is correct. He went on in that interview to say:
I think, that in fact, you might only have to use that sort of power [ie, directions power] once in a decade.

Let us put the record straight as to whether the Opposition is confused in relation to this dispute. The Leader of the Opposition, who led for the Opposition in this debate today, clearly indicated on 25 August that what the Government was doing was correct.

We need to look at what a few other members of the Opposition had to say to see where they stand. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), when addressing the National Press Club on 31 August 1989, said this:
I want it [the pilots dispute] settled in a way that undermines the centralised wage fixing system because I don't believe in the centralised wage fixing system.
The Leader of the Opposition, at a press conference on 31 August, said:
. . . look I am not here to advocate a settlement according to the Government's views.

The Opposition is clearly supporting the pilots' decision to act outside the system-a system which all other people in this nation seeking wage adjustments are prepared to accept. We are told over and over again by the Opposition that there should be secret ballots. At the press conference on 31 August, Mr Peacock said:

Firstly, on secret ballots, the mere fact that one union may vote in favour of the strike does not negate that as a proposition to be worked at. The reason for secret ballots is to ensure that the membership of a union has a direct say as to what they want to do and that it's not assumed by the leadership alone as we've found time again.

There has been a secret ballot in this dispute. The dispute was planned, as the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) said, months ago on the basis that the pilots would take a particular line. They took the line espoused by the Opposition that there should be a secret ballot. Once again, this is proof that the Opposition's position is clear in relation to this dispute. The Opposition has never mentioned whether another secret ballot needs to be held to undo the decisions that were taken in the first place. In other words, this option for negotiation has been closed off. I will quote other members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) spoke at the Victorian Employers Federation Industrial Relations Conference on 29 August and said the opposite. He said:

I have never understood the fetish some people have for secret ballots for strike action and for bans against compulsory unionism. The latter is not a problem in Australia and the former is rarely a deterrent to strike action.
Certainly it was not a deterrent to strike action in this case.

Quite clearly, this matter of public importance is an approach by the Opposition to attack the system that has operated successfully in this nation since 1983 when we took over from a government which, at that time, had no wages policy, no industrial relations policy and was in absolute chaos. The people of Australia are very concerned about the terrible damage that this dispute is doing to the economy and many sectors of the community. A comparison can be made between the industrial relations policies of the Government and the Opposition. A cake of a certain size is available to the employees in this nation. No matter which industry people work in, a certain amount of funds is available within the structure of that industry for wages. In the early 1980s, the policies of the coalition Government led to wage break-outs. We saw the policies of the present Opposition in action. Under those policies, the unemployed are eventually left to carry the burden. People in Australia have seen what happened and they would be horrified to think that that approach is being put forward by our opponents. I have not heard them say to the pilots, `If you want to go down our path bear in mind that at the finish there may not be 16,040 pilots; there may be only 1,000. And under our policy the pilots themselves will lose out in relation to employment opportunities'. That would be the result of that type of policy.

But a break-out within a system cannot be allowed to occur. When the greedy take more than their share, the burden of carrying that break-out falls on those at the bottom, the unemployed-the ones who eventually lose their jobs because the economy of the industry cannot carry them. That is the basic difference between our policies. Do we develop an industrial relations system, such as the one we have at present which has worked effectively? The proof of that system is in the 1.5 million jobs created for Australians; not a greedy grab for a few, but a system that has allowed people to go before the Industrial Relations Commission and develop their arguments for productivity, wage increases and adjustments while at the same time taking into consideration the whole economy-and that means people. It means that every industry has been able to develop a system and create more employment within the economic sector. That is the difference between the two policies. The Opposition's arguments today in clear support of the pilots' approach were put forward as a test case for its policy. If the pilots are successful the Opposition will claim that its system is the way to go. It will say to people, `Get out there and bargain for what you can get. Use your strength'. Of course, that would mean more for the strong and less for the weak. We reject that system entirely.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), blamed the accord, of all things, for causing the dispute. Not once in his speech did he say that the pilots had anything to do with causing this dispute-it was the accord; not the pilots. I ask him a simple question: Why was he not prepared to say, at least in one sentence, that the pilots had some effect in initiating this dispute? They certainly planned it. They certainly had a secret ballot to have the dispute. They certainly decided to strand Australian people wherever they could and whenever they could. It is not true, as the Leader of the National Party said, that they had very little to do with it. He said it was the accord that forced them into it. He then said that there should be negotiations.

The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) has been on the phone talking to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, which is no longer in the system. Its employees are not able to speak about the dispute. If we want proof of that we need look no further than at the interview with Sir Peter Abeles on AM of 6 September 1989. In answer to a question from John Shovelan, Sir Peter Abeles said:

. . . we sincerely hope to fly them very soon because we offered-contrary to what Mr McCarthy and his group is permanently saying on every program-that we are not prepared to talk to our employees, or ex-employees because they are ex-employees, the one's who haven't signed up. We offered to talk to them.

There are opportunities for negotiations to take place. The Opposition has put itself in a corner which it will have great difficulty getting out of. At the next election the Australian people will have the choice of voting for policies that will cause chaos or for policies that have been proven in the last seven years and have created 1.5 million jobs. The structure in which those jobs have been created must be maintained. We will continue to maintain it.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the House of Representative Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure I am making a statement to the House on behalf of the Committee on whether Mr Christopher Charles Skase, Chairman of Qintex Ltd, misled the Committee in evidence he gave before it on 15 June 1988. This evidence was given the inquiry into the role and functions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). The Committee reported on this and other evidence on 1 December 1988. The origins of this statement have the following sequel of events. On 5 July 1989 the Sydney Morning Herald published an article which said that Mr Skase `appears to have given conflicting evidence to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and a parliamentary committee on his reasons for buying two television stations through a shelf company, Kaycliff Pty Ltd'. On 5 July 1989, whilst on Committee business in Kalgoorlie, I was contacted by a Sydney Morning Herald reporter on this matter and indicated that the Committee would examine these allegations. The Sydney Morning Herald of the next day, 6 July, carried the following headlines, `Inquiry ordered into Skase evidence'.

SPEECH.PARA: I brought this matter to the attention of the Committee at a special meeting on 11 July 1989. The Committee resolved that I consult with the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), and report to the Committee on whether the evidence Mr Skase gave misled the Committee. For the information of honourable members, Qintex Ltd, through a chain of companies which it owns or controls, owns the Australian Television Network, Channel 7. In April 1988 the Perth TVW and Adelaide SAS television stations were purchased through a company called Kaycliff Pty Ltd, which does not hold any other interests in any of the television licences held in the Qintex group. Mr Skase held five of the 100 shares of Kaycliff.

The honourable member for Mayo and I have examined the relevant sections of the Committee transcript of 15 June 1988 during which Mr Skase was questioned with regard to Kaycliff Pty Ltd. We also examined the transcript of evidence taken from a hearing of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the period from 10 April 1989 to 12 April 1989, during which time Mr Skase was questioned with regard to his purchase of the Perth and Adelaide television stations. The honourable member for Mayo and I have come separately to the same conclusion after full examination of those transcripts that there is no inconsistency in information provided at our hearing on 15 June 1988 and the evidence given at the hearings of the ABT during April this year. It may be that what Mr Skase told the Tribunal in May 1988 was different from what he told the Committee a month later. But what he told the Tribunal in 1989 was not inconsistent with what he told the Committee. He made it clear to us that he controlled Kaycliff, an assurance he also gave the Tribunal, and that he knew the purchase of the Perth and Adelaide stations would put him above the audience reach limits. He also made it clear that this was not in itself illegal.

In reading the transcripts of both hearings it is clear that the direction of questioning at the Tribunal hearing was somewhat different from that taken by the Committee. The Committee was more concerned with the possible misuse of the period of grace inserted into the Act in 1981; whereas the Tribunal questioning appeared to concentrate on the ownership and control provisions of the Act. It is useful to note how the Committee viewed the Skase evidence. The Committee report stated:

5.46 The periods of grace under the Act are deliberately being used to acquire excess interests, with a view to corporate restructuring and advantageous disposal of the excess (if at all) at a more convenient later date, and possibly to a carefully selected purchaser. The Committee regards this as an abuse of the legislation.
5.52 In conjunction with the above, the Committee further recommends that:
Recommendation 14:
(B) The `periods of grace' under the Act for the disposal of excess interest should be amended to ensure that they cannot be used deliberately to acquire excess interests.

The Deputy Chairman and I have reported our views to the Committee, which has endorsed them. This short statement has been made pursuant to that endorsement. The Committee has concluded that Mr Christopher Skase did not mislead the Committee in the evidence he gave before it on 15 June 1988. We are therefore of the view that no further action should be taken other than to report our findings to the House and to inform the relevant parties of our findings. The announcement of this inquiry by the Committee was given some prominence in the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 July 1989. I trust that this statement will receive the same treatment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill introduces measures to give effect to some of the Treasurer's 1989-90 Budget announcements. The income tax law will be amended to require major employers to remit pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) tax deductions, withheld from the salary or wages of their employees, to the Commissioner of Taxation on a twice-monthly basis. Other Budget announcements to be given effect will vary the operation of the quarterly provisional tax system and provide for the method of calculating 1989-90 provisional tax. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will now outline in more detail these measures.
Twice-monthly remittance of tax instalment deductions

The Bill will require some employers registered under the group employer scheme to pay to the Commissioner of Taxation on a twice-monthly basis, the PAYE tax instalment deductions they make from the salary or wages of their employees on or after 1 December 1989. Employers affected by this change will be those who deducted more than $5m in tax instalments in the financial year ended 30 June 1989, or who do so in a later financial year. Employers who are members of a wholly-owned company group may also be required to remit their tax instalment deductions to the Commissioner on a twice-monthly basis. This rule will apply where the total amount of the deductions made by all the employers in the company group during the financial year ended 30 June 1989, or in a later year, exceed $5m. Employers who are subject to the new rules will be required to pay all deductions made in the first 14 days of a month by the twenty-first day of that month.

Deductions made in the balance of the month are to be paid over by no later than the seventh day of the next month. Once employers start to remit tax instalment deductions on a twice-monthly basis they must continue to do so unless the Commissioner determines otherwise because of a significant change in their circumstances. This measure is the first step towards revised PAYE remittance arrangements that would require larger employers to remit twice-monthly but with less frequent remittances than at present by smaller employers, which could obviate the need for the tax stamps system. The amendment will produce a one-off revenue gain of $550m in 1989-90. Additionally, outlays on public debt interest will reduce by $20m in 1989-90 and $70m in subsequent years.
Quarterly provisional tax

The Bill will give effect to two Budget proposals adjusting the operation of the quarterly instalment system of paying provisional tax. The threshold for general exemption from the instalment system will be increased from $5,000 to $8,000. As a consequence, a taxpayer whose provisional tax payable in a year of income is $8,000 or less will not be required to pay instalments of provisional tax in the following year. This change will apply to provisional tax payable in the current and subsequent income years. Some 130,000 of the existing 320,000 instalment payers will now be required to pay provisional tax only on an annual basis. Of this large number who will benefit from the change, some 45,000 are over 60 years of age.

This proposal is estimated to increase outlays on public debt interest by $20m in 1989-90 and $70m in subsequent years. The Bill will also give effect to another proposal to preclude a too early offset of provisional tax credit in a year of income against provisional tax charged for the succeeding year. Credit arises where income tax assessed as payable for an income year is less than the credit for provisional tax previously paid for that year. Under the change, any excess provisional tax credit will no longer be offset against a quarterly instalment of provisional tax for the succeeding year which has been notified but is not yet due for payment. This change will apply from the date of royal assent to the Bill.
Provisional tax for 1989-90

Provisional tax is that part of the pay-as-you-earn system designed to collect tax on non-salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived. It follows that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year. This Bill provides for 1989-90 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1988-89 taxable income increased by 10 per cent, and by applying the 1989-90 rates of tax, Medicare levy and the increased low income thresholds for Medicare levy that are to apply in that year. Subject to the exceptions I will announce, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1988-89 assessments. Any rebate of tax allowed on franked dividends will be adjusted, before being increased by 10 per cent, to account for the reduction in the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent.

In addition, credits for foreign tax paid will be uplifted by 10 per cent. Concessional rebates claimed in 1988-89 for a dependent spouse, daughter-housekeeper, invalid relative, parent or parent-in-law or for a housekeeper and the sole parent rebate will be adjusted to reflect the new higher 1989-90 levels. Changes will also be made to some claims for zone rebates and the rebates for Defence Force members serving overseas or civilians serving with the United Nations. The 1989-90 provisional tax will be calculated after increasing any such rebate by 20 per cent of the adjustment made to the taxpayer's 1988-89 concessional rebate claim. Taxpayers who estimate that their taxable income from 1988-89 will increase by less than 10 per cent, or who consider that their rebates or credits will be at a higher level in 1989-90, will continue to have the right to `self assess' and have the provisional tax for 1989-90 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates. The reduction in the uplift factor from the 12 per cent that was applied in calculating 1988-89 provisional tax to 10 per cent for 1989-90 provisional tax is estimated to cost $160m in 1989-90.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a national scheme for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals to protect people at work, the public and the environment from the harmful effects of industrial chemicals. The scheme will be known as the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme-NICNAS. This scheme will form a vital component in an overall chemicals management strategy for Australia. Notification and assessment of chemicals will improve the efficiency of other elements of this overall strategy such as labelling, provision of material safety data sheets and education and training.

The Bill reflects the continuing priority that the Federal Government gives to ensuring safe Australian workplaces and a cleaner environment. Worksafe Australia and the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council, whose 1984 proposal was the basis for this legislation, have conducted consultations with Commonwealth departments, State and Territory authorities, unions and industry and other interested groups to ensure that the proposed scheme will take into account and achieve a fair balance between the interests of these parties.

The legislation is to apply to industrial chemicals imported into or manufactured in Australia. It will apply to the individual chemical substances, but not mixtures or formulations. Because it is not possible to determine the hazards of a formulation unless the properties of the ingredients are known, this scheme will also provide the fundamental information with which formulations can be assessed.

This legislation will not place controls on chemicals. This will necessarily be through the existing body of State and Territory legislation. The legislation will, however, promote the development of uniform controls by ensuring that adequate, independently reviewed information is available to State and Territory authorities, and by making recommendations about appropriate controls for national adoption.

Industrial chemicals are used in virtually every commodity, including textiles, paints, plastics, adhesives and cleaners, and are an integral part of modern life. Over the past several decades the number of industrial chemicals introduced by industry has increased dramatically. It has been estimated that, worldwide, there are in excess of 100,000 individual industrial chemicals in commercial use. Over 30,000 of these are used in Australia and found in a bewildering number of chemical products.

This legislation is long overdue. Unlike therapeutic drugs and agricultural and veterinary chemicals, industrial chemicals are, and have been, introduced into Australian workplaces and the environment without any national assessment of their hazards. This is in stark contrast to the majority of our trading partners who have had similar legislation in place for a number of years. This legislation will ensure that new industrial chemicals are evaluated before they enter the Australian market, and that selected chemicals already in use are reviewed.

Control over industrial chemicals is currently exercised by the States and Territories through many and various pieces of legislation, covering, for example, the transport and storage of dangerous goods, occupational health and safety, consumer protection and environmental protection. To date, standards and controls for chemicals have largely been developed on a piecemeal basis by individual States and Territories, often only in response to damage to health or environmental pollution. Differences in approach between States and Territories have led to a lack of uniformity in requirements and controls. This situation results in significant, unnecessary costs for industry, as well as increased hazard to the public and the environment.

Honourable members will be aware of the enormous cost of rectifying the damage done by chemicals such as mercury, polychlorinated biphenyls and asbestos. Hardly a day goes by without an incident being reported involving hazardous chemicals, whether it is a chemical fire in Melbourne or pollution of an historic waterway in Sydney. Such incidents have led to international recognition of the need to anticipate potential hazards of chemicals prior to their entry into commerce.

Based on extrapolation of overseas data, the cost of occupational injury and disease from exposure to chemicals can be expected to be very high. As a consequence, even modest reductions will have major benefits in monetary and human terms. For example the United Kingdom Health and Safety Executive has recently estimated that seven million working days are lost each year in the United Kingdom due to skin problems, at a cost of $A1.3 billion. Occupational dermatitis resulting from chemical exposure makes up the `large majority' of these skin problems.

The public is exposed to industrial chemicals directly through use of consumer products and indirectly by the presence of these chemicals in the environment through pollution. Contamination resulting from release of industrial chemicals to the environment has many negative effects apart from those to human health. Pollution of waterways leads to loss of environmental amenity-for example, swimming or recreational fishing-and also economic loss; for example, to commercial fishing industries. Accumulation of chemicals in animals, particularly those at the top of food chains, can threaten individuals and, on occasions, place entire species at risk.

The exaggerated fear of chemicals has in recent years become a source of considerable cost and delay to both industry and government. Such fears can result in industrial action against changes in workplace processes using chemicals and adverse community reaction to proposals for new chemical plants, waste disposal and destruction facilities. A persistent complaint of workers, environmental groups and the general public is the lack or inadequacy of chemicals information. Clearly a mechanism is required in Australia to ensure that sufficient data is provided for new chemicals to permit the adequate assessment of their potential health and environmental hazards. In this way the safeguards recommended will properly reflect both the potential exposure to the chemical and its physical, chemical and toxicological properties. Such a mechanism should not, however, impose unnecessary time or cost burdens on industry. The establishment of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, otherwise known as Worksafe Australia, in 1985 was early evidence of the Government's commitment to occupational health and safety. The scheme will be administered by Worksafe Australia.

Turning to the details of the legislation, part 2 of the Bill refers to the Australian Inventory of Chemical Substances. This central feature of the legislation is currently being compiled by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The inventory will list those industrial chemicals which are already in use in Australia and which therefore will not be regarded as new under this legislation. Chemicals listed in this inventory, and certain other chemicals, will be exempted from the requirements for new chemicals. These may be reviewed if they give rise to concern. New chemicals which are notified and assessed under the scheme will not be added to the inventory for a period of five years after the assessment has been completed. This will prevent others who wish to introduce the chemical from unfairly profiting from the work of the original applicant in satisfying the requirements of the legislation.

Part 3 of the Bill describes the process of notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. New chemicals will be notified to Worksafe Australia together with a notification statement of the chemical's intended use and properties. The cost of providing this information will be borne by the importer or manufacturer. The information will be assessed to determine the potential hazard to occupational health and safety, public health and the environment. The information required is similar to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) minimum premarketing set of data, which has been agreed internationally as that necessary for an initial hazard assessment of new industrial chemicals.

There are provisions in the legislation to provide a lesser information package if it is justified on scientific or economic grounds. For example, in the case of polymers, small volume chemicals, research and development chemicals and site limited chemicals it is recognised that parts of the prescribed minimum data set may not be appropriate. These classes of chemicals are therefore subject to special consideration. For chemicals which have been in use overseas and are on overseas inventories this Bill provides discretion to allow an incomplete notification statement. On the other hand, in a small minority of cases, data beyond the prescribed minimum level may be required; for example, chemicals for which there is widespread human or environmental exposure or those chemicals for which the basic data package foreshadows a need for further information.

To ensure that occupational health and safety, public health and environmental health hazards are considered, assessments will be undertaken jointly by Worksafe Australia, the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories respectively. For each chemical, the information package, including the material safety data sheet, will be reviewed to determine appropriate recommendations for the safe use of the chemical. A consolidated assessment report will be prepared within prescribed timeframes by Worksafe Australia and distributed to responsible Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities. As it is sometimes necessary to review assessments to ensure that the original one remains valid, the Bill provides a mechanism for secondary notification. For instance, secondary notifications may be required for chemicals if they are used in a wider variety of applications than originally intended or if new information about their properties becomes available.

Several important provisions exist for the estimated 30,000 existing chemicals, which are listed on the inventory. These provisions allow the Federal Government to tackle, on a priority basis, those chemicals for which there are particular Australian concerns. In some cases, classes of chemicals which are related either by chemical structure or by their use or function may be declared as priority existing chemicals. In selecting existing chemicals for review, maximum use will be made of international collaborative efforts such as the OECD chemicals program and the United Nations international program on chemical safety.

There will be no prescribed information requirements for the assessment of existing chemicals. Instead an initial request for information will be made to assist in defining the extent of the problem. Information requirements will generally be directed to the specific concerns which prompted the review. Where only one aspect of a chemical is of concern, for example, environmental damage, information requirements and assessment may be limited to that aspect.

One important outcome of this scheme is the information on chemicals that will become available to the public. A summary of each assessment report will be published in a special issue of the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and the full public assessment report will be available on request. Confidentiality of information will be maintained when this is necessary to safeguard commercial interests. However, there will be a prescribed set of basic information, including summaries of health and environmental effects, which cannot be confidential.

The appeal provisions in the Bill are drawn widely. Industry and third parties will be able to appeal decisions made under the legislation to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. For example, appeals may be made against the content and recommendations of an assessment report or the selection of priority existing chemicals. The openness of the scheme, as evidenced by availability of information and by the wide appeal provisions, is unique, and is to be commended.

The Bill includes a number of offences. It also sets out the levels of fines to apply to a natural person and to a corporation. Consistent with standard practice, the maximum fine for a corporation is five times that for a natural person. The detailed implementation of controls and their enforcement will be the subject of memoranda of understanding to be developed between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. Proposals for regulating hazardous substances at the State and Territory level are being developed to be consistent with this legislation. For this reason there are provisions in the Bill to declare equivalent State and Territory schemes.
Financial Impact Statement

The costs of implementing this legislation are estimated to be $1.25m after 50 per cent cost recovery. Cost recovery is consistent with the practice established in August 1987 for the review of agricultural chemicals and veterinary drugs. Fees will be specified by regulation. The legislation has been developed to achieve its objectives at the minimum possible cost and includes significant provisions to allow flexibility in application to minimise impact on industry. Information required for both new and existing chemicals is limited to that necessary to perform an adequate hazard assessment of the chemical. The inclusion of statutory timeframes for assessment will ensure that hazards will be promptly reviewed and delays and uncertainties for industry minimised. Harmonisation of the scheme with those in operation in most OECD countries, and adoption of agreements on such matters as chemical test methods, good laboratory practice and mutual acceptance of data, allow a system of notification of new chemicals which does not duplicate equivalent testing and assessment processes carried out by other countries.

The provisions of the Bill specifically make maximum use of overseas assessments resulting in reduction of costs. Where the chemical has been notified and assessed under a recognised equivalent scheme of another country, that notification and assessment will suffice providing it is accessible and relevant to Australia. On the other hand, there may be occasions where additional tests are required because of unique Australian circumstances. The Bill allows for such occasions.

It is not suggested that the proposed legislation will, in itself, solve all the problems associated with hazardous chemicals and the considerable costs that flow from these. However, even small percentage reductions in the damage caused by chemicals represent very substantial benefits to Australia. The Bill, operating in conjunction with other mechanisms such as requirements for material safety data sheets, will maximise these benefits.

It is the Government's intention that the commitment of industry and trade unions to the scheme be maintained and their involvement continued. To this end, an advisory committee will be established within the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. In addition, a coordinating committee will be established external to the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to deal with issues of common concern to interested departments and to provide advice to the Government on the development and operation of the scheme after its inception.

Major effects of the scheme will be evident in the areas of occupational health and safety and protection of the environment. Overall, we believe that real benefits will follow because the legislation will encourage uniformity of regulation by the States and Territories; require those introducing chemicals to `know their products', to be aware of the chemical's identity and properties; and increase rational debate in the community on chemicals issues.

This Bill provides another strong indication of the Government's desire to ensure that significant occupational health and environmental issues confronting society are managed effectively and safely. Chemicals are an essential part of our society and require responsible management by manufacturers and importers, workers and consumers as well as by government. The provisions of this Bill show that the Government is addressing this important area. I believe this Bill represents an important step in the management of an extremely complex issue. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
