DEBATE.TITLE: HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to control the export and import of hazardous wastes in order to protect human health and the environment. The Act will enable Australia to take part in international measures to control the movement of hazardous wastes which also have this objective. With the development of modern industry has come the generation of hazardous industrial and chemical wastes. These are wastes that cannot be disposed of in municipal landfill or the sewer, but need to be recorded and tracked to special treatment and disposal facilities. In the last two decades it has become recognised in every industrial country that special regulation is needed for these materials. Consequently, in industrialised countries such special regulation has been put in place, to protect the environment. In Australia, regulation of hazardous wastes is primarily a State and Territory responsibility and they administer appropriate controls. In this area of regulation, in Australia and overseas, the term hazardous wastes does not include radioactive wastes, which have separate regulatory needs. In this country the import and export of radioactive materials are controlled under the Customs Act.

It became clear as national control systems were developed that gaps existed at national borders. Well publicised incidents, such as drums of waste being `lost' at European borders, or wastes being dumped in African ports, led to the conclusion that an international control system was necessary to protect the global environment. This was recognised by the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, which recommended in its 1982 First Report on the Inquiry into Hazardous Chemicals that Australia should control the export and import of these materials. Subsequently the Australian Environment Council endorsed Commonwealth control on exports and imports of hazardous wastes. I should add that there is no evidence that Australia has been involved in unacceptable movement of these materials.

The international body which acted first in this area was the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). In 1984 it began developing international agreements to control hazardous wastes when moved, to ensure their satisfactory disposal. However, it became clear that a global agreement was necessary, and in 1987 the initiative was taken by the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP). In the light of these developments, the Government decided in March 1988 to control this trade in order, amongst other things, to take part in international control arrangements.

On 22 March 1989, at a UNEP conference held in Switzerland, the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal was unanimously adopted by all governments represented. Australia was active in drawing up the Convention. Australia can become a party to the Convention once this legislation has been put into effect. Before becoming a party the Commonwealth will consult with the States and Territories. Fundamental features of the Basel Convention include: the requirement that parties shall prohibit the export of hazardous wastes from their jurisdictions to States that do not consent to the import; the requirement that countries treating and disposing of wastes do so in an environmentally sound manner; and the tracking of wastes to acceptable disposal, when moved across borders.

In essence the Bill before us provides for the issuing of permits to control both the import and export of hazardous wastes to ensure that they are disposed of by an environmentally acceptable method. The legislation has been designed to control the movements of wastes as required by the Convention. However, several of the obligations in the Convention, such as the requirement to minimise waste production and the provision of acceptable disposal facilities, fall within the responsibilities of State and Territory governments. Therefore the controls introduced by this Bill will be complemented by State and Territory waste management legislation.

At present, a few hundred tonnes of hazardous waste are exported from Australia each year. These wastes fall into the category of intractable wastes for which the only widely acknowledged environmentally acceptable method for disposal is high temperature incineration. The majority of those wastes that have been exported have been sent to Pontypool in the United Kingdom for destruction in a high temperature incinerator. As far as is known no hazardous wastes have been imported into Australia.

As I mentioned, hazardous wastes are generally defined as those wastes that cannot be disposed of in the usual way such as to municipal landfill or the sewer. They present a potential threat to the environment or human health and therefore require special treatment. However, in addition to what are usually considered to be hazardous wastes, the Basel Convention also controls the movement and disposal of wastes collected from households and residues arising from the incineration of household wastes. Accordingly, the definition of hazardous wastes in the Bill has been expanded to include these categories of wastes.

The Bill provides that the Minister must issue a permit for the export of wastes only if he or she is satisfied, amongst other things, that the hazardous waste will be permitted to enter the proposed country of import and that any exported waste will be disposed of in the receiving country in a manner that will not be harmful to the environment. It will be necessary for the applicant for either an import or export permit to demonstrate that he or she has adequate insurance or is able to meet any liability arising in relation to the activity proposed.

Other matters that the Minister may take into account when considering an export application are whether there are facilities for disposal of wastes in Australia which could be used for the disposal of the exports. This ground could be used to make more viable Australian treatment facilities. It is also consistent with the Basel Convention, which seeks to minimise movements whenever possible. The Minister may also take into account Australia's international relations, when considering issuing permits. Other clauses in the Bill provide for the Minister to vary, extend and revoke permits, with appropriate safeguards for applicants. Particulars of permits are to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, unless there are national interest reasons not to do so.

Under the Bill, the Minister may make orders to deal with the wastes and recover costs if the orders are not complied with. This power will include the power to order wastes illegally imported to Australia to be returned to the country of origin. This is consistent with the Basel Convention. Principal offences under the Bill will be punishable by up to five years imprisonment. Enforcement of the Act will be by inspectors with appropriate powers. The Bill provides for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, against the Minister's decisions whether such decisions are to grant or not to grant a permit, to vary or not to vary a permit, or other decisions relating to permits. Third parties with an interest may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill provides for amendment of the Customs Act to ensure that where hazardous wastes are the subject of illegal movement under the proposed Act, they are not thus forfeit to the Crown. Hazardous wastes have a negative value, that is ownership of them is a liability. Therefore a person should not be able to get rid of them simply by illegally importing or exporting them and then forfeiting them to the Crown. There is provision for fees of up to $4,000 to be paid by permit applicants. It is intended that these will cover the costs of administering the Act.

The States and Territories have been consulted during the drafting of the Bill. Their cooperation will be needed in the administration of the Act through, for example, informing the Commonwealth authorities of suspected illegal import or export activities. Memoranda of understanding will be developed with them for this purpose.

The Government is committed to ensuring that hazardous wastes in Australia are managed in an environmentally acceptable manner. The introduction of controls on the import and export of hazardous wastes complements the domestic regulation of these materials which the Commonwealth is helping to implement through the Australia and New Zealand Environment Council, formerly the Australian Environment Council to which I referred earlier. The Commonwealth, in concert with the States and Territories, is encouraging industry to minimise its production of hazardous wastes. Many companies are now finding that waste minimisation is in fact cost-effective in terms of the valuable materials that can be recovered from the so called `waste' stream. This Government, together with the New South Wales and Victorian State governments, is examining the possibility of establishing a facility for the high temperature incineration of intractable wastes in New South Wales. The incinerator is proposed as a national facility but, if established, it will be operated by a New South Wales government agency. Setting up such a facility would reduce the current need to store or export intractable wastes.

Australia has as its near neighbours many small nations, such as the Pacific countries, which may well have relatively small quantities of hazardous wastes which they wish to dispose of safely. Australia has a responsibility to assist these countries to dispose of their wastes in an environmentally acceptable manner. It is inconceivable that these nations could justify the building of a high temperature incinerator given the small amount of wastes that would need to be incinerated. Accordingly, if the wastes are to be disposed of safely in our region, it may be necessary to import those wastes into Australia for incineration. Through the adoption of the measures contained in the Bill, Australia will be in a position to control the movement of hazardous wastes into and out of Australia and to require that these wastes are only treated and disposed of using methods of the highest standard. In this way we can demonstrate to the rest of the world our commitment to the protection of the global environment.
I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION AND OTHER BENEFITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

Pensions payable to, or in relation to, most former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel are increased in July each year in accordance with the increase in the weighted average of the consumer price index for the eight capital cities to the previous 31 March. In 1986, the extraordinary circumstances of the economy required all members of the community to share the cost of reducing government expenditure. As part of these arrangements, the Government legislated in October 1986 for the 2 per cent wage discount that had been applied to wages to be extended to the 1986 pension increase applied to Government superannuation benefits payable to, or in respect of, former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel. Since 1986 those pensions payable to former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel have been adjusted by the full consumer price index increase. Persons receiving those pensions have therefore suffered a significantly lower reduction in living standards than the average person in the work force at the time when real wages for full-time adult workers have fallen by 2.2 per cent since 1982. In the context of the decision announced in the April statement to bring forward indexation increases of social welfare benefits by 12 weeks, the Government also decided that former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel whose 1986 pension increases were reduced would have the level of those pensions restored from November 1989.

The purpose of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill is to implement the Government's decision. It amends the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948, the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976 and the Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) (Superannuation) Regulations to provide for the levels of pensions payable under that legislation to be increased from 20 October 1989. This is the first day in the pay period which ends on the first pension payday in November. Pensions will be increased from that date to the levels that would have applied if they had not been reduced in October 1986. The increase will be applied only to pensions directly or indirectly affected by the 1986 reduction.

It is expected that, as a result of the proposed amendments, total costs of the relevant pensions during 1989-90 will increase by approximately $17m and during 1990-91 by approximately $27.7m. Increases in outlays effects are estimated at $12.1m for 1989-90, and $19.8m for 1990-91.

DEBATE.TITLE: FITOUT OF CIVIL AVIATION AUTHORITY HEADQUARTERS BUILDING, CANBERRA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provision of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Fitout of the Civil Aviation Authority headquarters building, Canberra.

The proposed work, recommended by the Public Works Committee, is the fitout of a building to house the headquarters of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in Canberra. The Civil Aviation Authority purchased building No. 6 of the National Convention Centre in March 1989. The building has only very recently been constructed. It was purchased for $49.5m as a commercial investment with the aim of reducing the long term cost of providing office accommodation in Canberra. The fitout work extends over 16,500 square metres of floor space and will cost an estimated $13.4m at July 1989 prices.

The work is being designed to comply with the requirements of relevant authorities and will combine individual offices with open plan office space, using modern systems furniture to handle cabling requirements and to promote flexibility. Extensive consultation has occurred with staff associations and examples of the proposed systems furniture have been set up to permit staff comment. In order to ensure earliest termination of existing leasing costs totalling $350,000 per month, the CAA seeks to achieve completion in early 1990. I thank the Committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this report from the Joint Committee on Public Works and trusts that the work will be able to be speedily undertaken and completed early in 1990. Obviously, with a saving of $350.000 per month, we would hope that those savings can be made at the earliest opportunity. The Opposition joins with the Government in thanking the Committee for its work on this project.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF ADDITIONAL DOMESTIC APRON FACILITY AT SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of an additional domestic apron facility at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

There is currently a shortage of domestic apron facilities at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to accommodate jet aircraft ranging from small corporate jets to larger wide-bodied domestic aircraft. The situation is expected to become more critical following deregulation of the domestic aviation industry in October 1990. The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is proposing the development of an additional apron facility to meet this need. The proposed apron will utilise the largely undeveloped area in the north-east sector of the airport, which is conveniently located close to the existing domestic terminal aprons. It will be capable of accommodating six domestic jet aircraft and additional stand-off positions for smaller aircraft. The scope of the work includes associated engineering infrastructure and the relocation of some roads and staff car parks near the present entry to the domestic terminal complex.

The FAC has advised that the works will cost an estimated $9.6m at May 1989 prices. In order to ensure that additional domestic aprons are available by the October 1990 deregulation of the domestic aviation industry, the FAC seeks to award a contract as early as possible in 1990 and to achieve completion by October 1990. I table layout drawings showing the extent of the proposed works and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this initiative and wishes the Public Works Committee well with this particular project. As the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) rightly said in his statement, there is almost a desperate need for this work to be completed as soon as possible in light of the fact that Australia will be entering domestic airline deregulation on 31 October next year. During the parliamentary recess I managed to visit Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and have a look at this site to the north-west of the airport complex. I understand that there is already some space available there but, obviously, if it is going to take up to six additional domestic jets there will have to be some extension.

SPEECH.PARA: While it is not particularly mentioned in the Minister's speech, I commend the Federal Airports Corporation for its negotiations with the prospective new carriers in the domestic aviation business for trying to get together some form of plan for the development of a joint user facility terminal adjacent to this apron space. That is going to be essential. Obviously, if domestic deregulation is going to work from the end of October next year we must have the proper infrastructure available. It has been indicated by some of the prospective new players that, without that infrastructure, they may not be able to start their operations. So there is some urgency in this inspection and recommendation from the Public Works Committee. I would certainly wish this inquiry a speedy resolution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hobart Mercury of 29 August reports that a group of long term unemployed men who embarked on a Newstart course have slammed it as impractical. I will give some quotes from the newspaper article. It states that these men:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . are frustrated at not receiving specific training for occupations such as aluminium welding or cabinet making where there are labour shortages.
The article goes on:
But surely, someone could investigate where the jobs are and give us the training needed for them.''
The men also believe the course structure is more an attempt to keep the unemployment figures down and the training statistics up.

What an indictment of the Newstart program when the course structure is designed to keep the unemployment figures down and the training statistics up. Surely what we need are courses that meet their objective, namely, to get the unemployed, and particularly the long term unemployed, and disadvantaged into the work force. The newspaper article goes on to state:
What riles the men most is that those who should be concerned about the failure or success of the course do not seem to care about their plight.

Although they have written to a number of politicians and union officials whose input and discussion they believe could make the course a viable alternative to the dole, there has been little response.
In the Adelaide Advertiser of 2 September there is another criticism of the Newstart course. The article states:
Car manufacturing companies with hundreds of jobs available cannot recruit workers despite Government schemes aimed at providing staff.
It goes on:
The Nissan recruitment manager . . . said that . . . he was advertising for staff through newspapers and radio but he still had difficulty finding acceptable applicants.
. . . he also said Nissan had not been able to recruit a single person taking part in Newstart despite a commitment by his company to give the program a go.

The Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who ought to be in the chamber listening to this debate on the appropriations for his Department, said that he was not surprised that some people applying for jobs under Newstart were seen as unsatisfactory. What kind of program is that? It is supposed to be a program designed for those people but the Minister says it is unsatisfactory.

This Government does not seem to understand that the social engineering associated with these training schemes will not work. What is needed is an incentive framework and a freer labour market if we are to realise the full employment potential of our citizens. We need an incentive framework of lower taxes to encourage employers to invest the necessary funds to ensure effective apprenticeship and trainee programs. We need a freer labour market with pay related to productivity to ensure that the pay scale relativities are such as to encourage employers to find the appropriate positions for their employees. Then and only then will we have an industrial situation that will make us more competitive internationally and so allow us to solve the massive overseas debt problem that this Government has brought on our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget is a fair deal for higher education in Australia. It convincingly affirms the Hawke Government's determination to dramatically increase and expand the higher education system in Australia. This Budget is also a practical testament to the tenacity and indomitable will of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to ensure that all qualified Australians have access to higher education. He is owed the gratitude of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Funding for higher education has been boosted by $843m and an extra 40,000 student places will be available over the next three years. By the end of 1991 about 130,000 student places will have been created beyond the 1983 level, a massive 50 per cent increase. During the 1989-91 triennium higher education will receive approximately $9 billion to sustain operating grants and new capital works. In contrast, during the 1976-82 period under the Fraser Liberal-National Government, funding for higher education decreased in real terms.

Yesterday the Minister for Employment, Education and Training announced that the Hawke Government had allocated $3.4 billion for higher education in 1992 to continue the massive building program now under way and also to fund an extra 14,000 new student places. This strategy of continuing expansion and funding will provide more opportunities for Australians from all walks of life to enjoy the benefits of higher education. Since the release in 1988 of the White Paper on Higher Education the Hawke Government will have increased funding for higher education by $1.3 billion. This is a magnificent accomplishment of which all Australians can be proud.

The pursuit of excellence, equity, access and growth is a hallmark of the Hawke Government's policy on higher education. The commitment of vast sums of money, nearly one per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), by the Hawke Government to higher education carries with it the duty by higher education institutions to be accountable for the money they receive on trust from the Australian people. Australia's higher education system must respond to national social and economic imperatives.

The rapid growth in higher education requires a huge expansion in capital facilities. Funding for capital works in this Budget will rise from $78.5m this year to $126.7m in 1989, $145.4m in 1990, $177.2m in 1991 and $191m in 1992. The 1992 funding allocation represents an increase of 125 per cent on the 1988 level and is recognition of the urgent need for adequate facilities to meet the growth in enrolments and the existing backlog in building projects, including new student residences.

This Budget provides a major expansion of funds for research. The annual budget available for competitive research will rise from $78m in 1988 to $140m in 1991. This is in line with the Hawke Government's commitment to the pursuit of excellence in higher education and its insistence that all research be of the highest quality and relevant to the national, social and economic aims of the nation. For this purpose an additional $138.5m has been allocated between 1990 and 1992. Over this period $107.5m will go to the maintenance and development of research infrastructure in higher education institutions and $31m for post-graduate research students including industry scholarships.

In 1990 there will be an increase of 150 in the number of research scholarships awarded and stipends will be at a non-tax- able rate of between $12,734 and $16,433. This is equivalent to a taxable level of $15,000 and $20,000 and is a dramatic increase-by 68 per cent and 125 per cent respectively-from the 1988 taxable level of $8,882. Furthermore, over the past year the Australian Research Council has increased its funding for research grants by 47 per cent, from $31.5m to $52.1m. The Council now funds 32 key centres for teaching and research including the Key Centre for Economic Geology at James Cook University at Townsville.

Under the inspired leadership of one of Australia's most distinguished academics and vice-chancellors, Professor Ray Golding, James Cook University of north Queensland is Australia's only major university north of the Tropic of Capricorn. It serves an area that stretches from Mackay in the south to Thursday Island in the north and westwards to the Northern Territory-Queensland border, an area of 747,800 square kilometres, and a population base of nearly 500,000 people.

James Cook University is the only higher education institution in a region three times the size of Victoria and with a population larger than that of Tasmania. Within this region the participation rate in higher education is one-third the Australian average-eight per thousand as against 25 per thousand nationally. Australians living in north Queensland are disadvantaged by isolation and distance. The current student population at James Cook University is about 5,000 and with a growth rate of 10 per cent per annum more than 6,000 students will be attending James Cook University by 1992. James Cook University is determined to bring participation rates in this region up to at least the national level. The policies of the Hawke Government demand no less.

To achieve this goal, James Cook University will broaden the range of its already extensive academic program by the addition of important disciplines-for example, nursing, creative arts and, within the Faculty of Engineering, a new discipline of building. Over the next few years, the tropical health and medicine programs in the Faculty of Science will expand considerably, leading to the introduction of a full medical school in about seven years. James Cook University has always placed strong emphasis on engineering, science and technology, economics and business studies including accounting and also intends to establish an Institute of Asian Studies. This is in recognition of the University's unique proximity to South East Asia.

James Cook University was Australia's first university in the tropics and from the beginning one of the objectives of James Cook University has been to encourage and provide facilities for study and research in relation to subjects of special importance to the tropics. It has achieved national and international acclaim in recognition of its high standard of research and research training in cyclone engineering, geosciences and geotechnology with special reference to the mineral industries, applications of computing, information sciences and electronic engineering, tropical veterinary science and animal production, human adaptation and cultures in the tropics, and marine science and technology.

James Cook University is giving special support to new research initiatives which have already attracted non-government funding but which involve collaborative research with industry and government. These include the Anton Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine under the leadership of the brilliant Dr Hedley Peach. James Cook University is also paying special attention to space technology and associated activities, now that moves to establish a space port on Cape York Peninsula are well under way.

In 1987 James Cook University established a campus in Cairns-350 kilometres north of Townsville-and through a successful fund raising appeal is acquiring land for the site. The university is also in the final stage of acquiring a facility at Mackay-400 kilometres south of Townsville-when it will then offer a program of undergraduate activities to serve the rapidly growing population in the Mackay-Whitsunday region.

The funding increase for capital facilities announced in this Budget is welcome news to James Cook University. For years the university has been starved of essential funding for new buildings and student accommodation. For the 1992 higher education building program the university has identified three essential priorities: a general purpose academic building primarily for commerce and economics, a biological sciences building and a mathematics and computer science building. In addition, the university requires at least 100 further places for student accommodation and it has requested a further $2.7m for student residential accommodation. A high level of accommodation on campus is essential in Townsville because of the limited rental accommodation available in a rapidly growing city with a large itinerant population. Many parents from rural areas send their children to the university only if accommodation on campus is guaranteed. By Australian standards, a high proportion of such places has been provided with substantial financial support from churches; but the 900 places available fall well below current demand. This acts as a serious limitation on the university's rate of growth and, consequently, on the desired increase in the participation rate.

One of the essential equity goals of James Cook University is to enhance the existing special programs for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. The Budget decision to create an additional 200 places for Aboriginal and Islander people is good news for a university which is dedicated to the educational advancement of more than 36,000 Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who live in North Queensland. I commend the Budget allocation for education, particularly for higher education. It will serve this nation well.

SPEECH.PARA: The growth in budgetary outlays has not seen an improvement in outcomes in a whole range of areas, including housing and health and in subprograms such as substance abuse, training, education and so on. Further, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal would, in our view, not assist that. The estimates of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs reveal that there is to be an allocation of some $9m for the ATSIC start-up costs. As far as I can see from looking at the estimates there is no breakdown as to where that money will actually go. My view is that under the ATSIC proposal, if it gets through the Senate-I can live in hope that it will not-the staff in existing agencies will be amalgamated under a new Commission. The estimates do not explain where these funds are being spent. I do not suppose that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) will respond to points made in this debate but I think that point needs to be made clear. The broader point is that the starting costs of ATSIC have been very expensive in terms of sheer money and the morale in the departments that administer Aboriginal affairs. There has been a great deal of discontent about the administration of Aboriginal affairs. That is not new to any of us in this place. There is a whole range of reasons for that, but the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country is a difficult task for whoever takes on the role of Minister, whether he is a Liberal or Labor Minister.

The support that experts in the field give to Ministers is particularly valuable and many in this place rely on it very heavily. In this area, when one is dealing primarily with very detailed and complex people problems, low morale is cause for concern. Many positions are vacant in Aboriginal administration in this country. SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is at present debating the appropriations of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It is my intention in my contribution to speak to the Department of Employment, Education and Training appropriations and, in particular, to youth affairs. The Employment, Education and Training portfolio deals principally with employment and training, labour market programs, education other than migrant adult education, the Commonwealth Employment Service, the coordination of research policy, research grants and fellowships, and youth affairs. In October last year the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his capacity as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Social Justice, announced that there would be a review of the Government's youth policy within a social justice context. They also indicated that in this review they would be considering all responses to the Burdekin report on the needs of homeless youth. At that time the Burdekin report had recently been released.

In the area of youth affairs, the achievements of the Government are substantial. Its youth strategy that was put in place in 1985 has achieved overall improvements in employment, education and training opportunities for young Australians. For example, the unemployment rate for 15- to 19-year-olds has fallen in six years from 22.8 per cent in May 1983 to 14.4 per cent in May this year. There has also been an increase in the proportion of young people staying on at school. Between 1983 and 1988 the figure increased from 62.4 per cent to 72.1 per cent for 16-year-olds, and from 33.6 per cent to 46.1 per cent for 17-year-olds. Nevertheless, the Government has recognised that some young people, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds, have not had full and equal access to these opportunities.

I refer honourable members to Budget Paper No. 7.6A, which contains the explanatory notes for the Employment, Education and Training portfolio. I refer in particular to table 6 on page 37. I want to raise a question in respect of retention rates which has played on my mind for some time. My electorate, by a whole host of criteria, can certainly be described as one containing young people from disadvantaged backgrounds. Table 6 shows a comparison of the changes in estimated year 12 completions by socioeconomc status (SES). According to the table, in 1984 the lowest decile in this so-called SES rating was 41.2 per cent and the highest decile was 75.9 per cent, giving an average of 48.8 per cent. Clearly, this shows that those in the higher socioeconomic portion of the community have a greater opportunity of completing year 12. The figures for 1987, which is part of the period that I have previously pointed out had an increase in the average retention rate from something like 44 per cent to a tick under 57 per cent, still show a wide range between the SES deciles-the lowest decile being 48.2 per cent and the top decile 80.1 per cent. The Government needs to pay full attention to the problem of retention rates to ensure that the gap between those two figures lessens. Not only should we in overall terms improve retention rates to year 12 but also we must introduce some form of justice and equity in the way that is achieved.

The other aspect of the Department's appropriations that I want to speak to briefly concerns the Skillshare program. I was flicking through some speeches that I made previously in this House and I noticed that two years ago in the committee stage debate of the 1987-88 Budget I spoke on this Department's appropriations. At that time the Government was considering the amalgamation of the then community youth support scheme (CYSS), the community training program and the community volunteer program. It was the consideration of those three programs that led to the introduction of Skillshare. At that time I was concerned that we were going from CYSS, which was directed at youth in particular, to a program that had a wider target group. I was concerned that there might be some problems in attracting youth into the scheme because of the way this program was implemented. I am pleased to see that that has not been as great a problem as I thought it might be. In fact, groups in my own electorate have managed to retain the participation of the younger age group as well as attracting the older, long term unemployed. Of course, there has been some strengthening of the labour market-type programs that these Skillshare groups have been able to offer by having a variety of age groups.

I particularly want to speak about one Skillshare program-Mature Action-which operates not only in my electorate but also in the general northern suburbs region of Melbourne. Mature Action started out under a community employment project grant and later got funding under a community training program. It has as its focus the older unemployed-people in the age group of 35 to 60. This is a quite difficult portion of the population to offer some hope and appropriate training to, but Mature Action has been able to do this with a great deal of success. I should perhaps indicate that this group started very much under the auspices of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) in his capacity as the honourable member for Jagajaga. TALK.START.PARA: —In the 10 minutes allotted to me in the consideration of the Defence estimates, I just want to raise some of the key issues which we face in defence for the next planning period. I will just go through these quickly, because there is limited time, and sketch them out. If we are to take an intelligent view of the requirements for adequate defence forces to protect Australia's security, first of all, there is a need for an integrated strategy for national security. At the moment there is a lack of an integrated strategy for national security-I will explain what I mean by that in a moment-and a lack of process for determining and updating such a strategy. By `national security strategy' I mean a strategy which involves the integration of foreign, economic, trade, defence and other policies in a forward looking way with the objective of maintaining peace in our region and in the hope that our defence forces will never be needed against any aggressor.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to achieve this integration has been most evident in South East Asia and in the south-west Pacific. A number of statements from different Ministers are in potential conflict. Until recently there was a distinct lack of interest in the south-west Pacific, for example, by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, and it certainly could not be said that one had any degree of confidence that the Government knew in advance the kinds of things that could happen in the region and that it was fully prepared to deal with them.

One of the reasons for the lack of the integrated strategy is that there is not an adequate process for linking politics with the departments in examining these issues together. There has to be a mechanism for ensuring that the Ministers in the Government who have the most clout-including the financial Ministers-are involved in advance in looking at national security strategy and are committed in advance to the kinds of preparations we need to take in defence and in other areas to meet that strategy.

Secondly, there are gaps in the defence strategy itself and the related force structure arising from inadequacies in the 1987 White Paper. I regard the 1987 White Paper as a considerable advance in defence thinking. In most respects I think it is quite a good document. It builds on the idea of self-reliance, which was introduced by the coalition Government in the 1976 White Paper, but it has certain gaps in it which have become quite evident and some of which have been highlighted by Kangaroo 89. For example, one of the major gaps in it is its failure to define what our commitment is in the surrounding region. I do not think anybody knows what kinds of things Australia believes it is responsible for in the region and, therefore, there has not been any clear definition of the force structure needed to deal with such contingencies. That is something that has to be resolved. There are other gaps relating to forward defence in that paper and they have to be sorted out. There are also equipment gaps which have not been filled, such as airborne early warning and control and mine counter-measures, called for in the 1987 White Paper but still not there.

The third issue is a poor resource allocation in defence itself, caused partly by Government failure to meet financial guidance targets, but also by inadequate internal management within defence. Here I do not mean military management-the military forces have their own management systems and they train people in command to manage the forces. I am talking about general management; I am talking about the kinds of things that the head of the Department, or the head of the Australian Defence Force (ADF), or those senior military and civil officers who have to make the main decisions within defence, have to worry about.

Within the time that has been made available to me and with the briefings I have had-and I am grateful for those briefings-I have identified serious failures in organisational structure and in management systems which mean that the defence organisation as a whole is not very good at all in assigning responsibilities for things. It is very hard to know who the boss is anywhere in defence and that is not terribly good, therefore, in allocating the vast resources which are under the control of the defence organisation. That is an issue that I will be developing at some length in succeeding weeks.

The next issue is really a part of that-the organisational structure of the Department itself, which I think is unsuited to the management requirements of the Department and the ADF. One of the things I have mentioned already-the difficulty of finding out who is actually responsible for anything-is one of the symptoms of that. Some improvements have been made in that following the Sanderson report, but I do not think that really gets to the heart of those kinds of problems.

The next issue is the outdated management information and control systems throughout the Department and the ADF. I have questioned those in naval support, for example, about how the enormous inventory in naval stores is managed. The management information and control systems and backup computer systems are very dated; they are not really adequately designed for modern management of such a major resource. I think there are big issues there.

The next area is the shortcomings in management of personnel and in service conditions. This has been dealt with by the Cross report, entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. Quite a lot of that needs to be looked at more thoroughly than has been done, but I acknowledge that something has been done about that. The main problem in morale is to do with management. I have been into many places where there has been poor personnel morale, of which there are instances in defence, as brought out by the Cross report. Of course, people complain about conditions of service and all that sort of thing, and that is part of it; but when one goes into an organisation and one finds difficulties concerning morale it is usually because of failures in management: the management systems are not clear enough; the responsibilities are not clear enough; people are not clear enough about who the real boss is and whether their boss has sufficient power to carry out the kinds of things they are responsible for; and, because of divisions of responsibility, inadequate management structures and inadequate delegation of financial responsibilities, there is a serious shortcoming in the kinds of management systems and approaches that would lead to higher morale.

I do not wish to overstress morale problems in all areas of the service. For example, when an exercise such as Kangaroo 89 is taking place one sees morale in the Services at its best because people are doing things. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has just entered the chamber and will acknowledge that when people are actively engaged in doing real tasks under command, people have a capacity to demonstrate their leadership and are responsible for that particular occasion, morale goes up. Unfortunately, that is not the norm. There are quite serious shortcomings in management organisation and systems which prevent, in the ordinary course of events in the defence organisation, people having a very clear idea who the boss is. For example, does the boss have real authority or is it constricted in ways that apparently are inexplicable to the person below? SPEECH.PARA: As I said during the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90, when one compares a number of the appropriations that were brought forward under the Hawke Government in this Budget, and indeed when one goes back to the last Budget of the last Liberal Government in 1982-83, it is interesting to note that at that time the defence appropriation was $4.6 billion. This year it is $8.3 billion. That represents an increase of a little over 80 per cent, and I worked it out as a compounding increase of around 9 per cent a year.

I would agree with most honourable members that it does not matter what one does with statistics, because one can come up with different answers depending on how one presents them. However, I present four sets of statistics to try to give honourable members a fuller appreciation of where defence funding has been and where it is going. As a percentage of gross domestic product, the average for the Fraser Government over seven years was 2.6 per cent. The average for the Hawke Government so far has been 2.6 per cent. This year it is 2.3 per cent, and it is likely to be around that figure in the next one or two Budgets. In the very unlikely event that the Opposition wins the next election, I suggest that that figure will probably not vary very much. The percentage of government outlays is interesting, because the average for the Fraser Government was 9.4 per cent. The average for the Hawke Government so far has been 9.5 per cent. This year it is 9.6 per cent. There is not much difference, but the percentage of government outlays has been a fraction higher under this Government than the previous Government.

It is interesting to look at the rate of real growth. Under the Fraser Government the average rate of real growth over and above the inflation rate was 2.5 per cent. The Fraser Government did very well, although when one compares the real growth figure with the government outlays figure it is slightly down. As one will see, it is way above the average for the Hawke Government. The average under the Hawke Government is 1.3 per cent. Of course, that comes about with the tightening of the budgetary situation in the last couple of years. There will be zero real growth this year and an estimated 2 per cent real growth in the next couple of Budgets. One could ask: What did the Fraser Government do with the money? As a percentage of expenditure on investments, which is basically capital equipment and the like, the Fraser Government spent an average of 19.1 per cent of the Budget on defence. The average expenditure of the Hawke Government on capital equipment is 29.1 per cent. So the figure is 19 per cent for the Fraser Government as against 29 per cent for the Hawke Government. This year it is 27.4 per cent.

This really gets back to the fundamental question that the honourable member raised about the 1987 White Paper and the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities 12 months earlier when we, on this side of the chamber, under the guidance of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), undertook a review that had not been undertaken before on the re-evaluation of our capabilities. Dibb identified what our capabilities were and what we needed. The aftermath of that was the review of that report and that 1987 White Paper. Everyone, including the honourable member for Mackellar, thought that the White Paper was an excellent document.

Out of that we have seen a tremendous lift in our capability. Indeed, there has been a rethink on the replacement mentality such as whether we needed all the tanks we kept replacing. Obviously we did not, because in a priority sense they did not do a lot for the defence of this country when compared with other items such as submarines, FA18 fighters, et cetera. This Government has continued with the submarine project-and I will say more about the Anzac frigate project in a second-and the replacement of the FA18 fighters continues. We have continued the Jindalee over the horizon radar system which will be developed further. I hope to see its completion as it will become a wonderful system. There will probably be three such systems across the north of Australia in the not too distant future.

All this has enhanced our defence self-reliance, or our defence in depth, as some people have called it, which concentrates on early interdiction; long range sea and air strike capability, which is being introduced-highly mobile ground forces for the Army-and the significant development and upgrading of our surveillance and intelligence facilities and operations. That is what this Government's defence policy is all about.

The submarine project and the Anzac frigate project are about to get under way. Looking at the overall expenditure of those two projects and all the others that are under way, such as Jindalee, around $12 billion worth of defence manufacturing will occur in Australia over the next decade. That is a massive amount and it is something that would not have occurred under a conservative government. Industry has been right up to the mark very early in the piece in relation to the submarine project and now the Anzac project because it has realised that this Government is genuine in its desire to build all those boats, submarines and Anzac frigates in Australia, and in New Zealand in regard to the latter. This would not have been done under a conservative government because there were elements within the Navy very early on in the submarine project that wanted them bought off the shelf. Later it was moved to the point where they wanted the first one or two bought overseas and the rest built here.

It was the committee I chair within the Government, which said, after discussions with the Minister, that it wanted a recommendation put to Cabinet that all the vessels be built here. That was done and approved by Cabinet, with some difficulties because such a project had not been undertaken before. We have seen two major projects, one on top of the other, put into play by this Government. Indeed, it is a resurrection of our defence manufacturing, our shipbuilding and our manufacturing industry in many parts, and the spin-offs from that, not just from the military area but commercially, will be vast in the coming years. With the involvement of the Swedes in the submarine project and now the Germans in the frigate program, I can envisage expenditures by those countries not only on those programs but also in other areas, particularly the commercial area.

This is an important Budget. Whilst this defence appropriation does not give any real growth it is significant, as I said earlier, that we have maintained an average growth of around nine per cent per year, which is a real increase of nearly 1 1/2 per cent. That will continue. A figure of two per cent is projected for the following year. Honourable members opposite cannot have it both ways: they cannot cut back fiscally, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) wants to do, and maintain real growth at the same time. We on this side have had a tight fiscal policy, and continued growth in defence, and the programs and capabilities of our Defence Force show up to the great delight of those who take an interest in our forces.

SPEECH.PARA: In yesterday's media reports and again last evening on the television program The 7.30 Report, many of us would have learnt of or seen the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) explaining the Government's decision to compensate a small number of Australian veterans involved in the British atomic tests at Maralinga in the 1950s for multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow. With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Chairman, I would like once again to precis the history of Mr Verwayen's case. This was relied upon as a specific defence against the claim of Mr Verwayen. In March 1986 the Government altered regulations to facilitate the imposition of the statute of limitations in relation to Voyager claims. At about the same time it also took certain psychiatric examination measures with specific claimants but seemingly discontinued those when the examination results favoured those claimants.

I refer honourable members to the Hansard record of this place on 9 December 1987 in which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) defended the Government's change of mind in 1985, at the same time imputing ulterior motives to those involved, including legal counsel. Is it not a fact that a firm of lawyers in Melbourne decided that it might be an opportunity to ginger up a bit of business?

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—Those imputations are rejected in the strongest terms. Indeed, they are disgraceful. In handing down their decision Mr Justice Kaye and Mr Justice Marks said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: There can be little doubt that the promise was made deliberately and with the knowledge and intention that Mr Verwayen pursue his claim and have his damages assessed.

In March 1989 the High Court of Australia granted the Commonwealth leave to appeal to that Court against the Victorian Supreme Court ruling. The two key Ministers involved in these matters, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Defence, are reasonable men under many circumstances. TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) focused upon an area of concern that he has brought to the shadow Defence portfolio, the issue of management. Throughout a number of the contributions he made this afternoon that particular theme, that hobby horse of his, was very obvious. I am appreciative, though, of the supportive comments of the honourable member for Mackellar, which, I am sure, will be appreciated by members of the Defence Force, particularly his comments supporting the Defence Force's involvement in Kangaroo 89.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the honourable member was an observer in that particular exercise, along with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and me. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also spent time there. A significant number of other members, particularly from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, took the time to go along to that exercise. It is very important that members of parliament take such opportunities to demonstrate in that public way that members of the Australian Defence Force follow a unique profession and that the profession of arms is a very valuable one which often is taken for granted.

Since I have had the privilege of having this portfolio, time and time again I have said that the public generally take for granted the men and women who serve in our Defence Force. Only in a time of natural disaster or when there is some sort of a defence emergency do people focus upon those people who serve their country in that way. Irrespective of our different views on the current crisis-the controversy with the internal airline dispute in Australia-I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the chamber very strongly support and appreciate the men and women who serve in the Royal Australian Air Force, in particular, for their contribution during this dispute. I certainly thank the honourable member for Mackellar for his supportive comments.

I will take up some of the other issues on management raised by the honourable member for Mackellar because I think they are important issues which need to be addressed in a very serious way. The honourable member asked just who is the boss in Defence. If one took it to its logical extreme, one could say that those people who have ministerial responsibility to some extent are the bosses within Defence, but I know that he is talking much more in terms of the day to day management. The honourable member talked about integrated strategies and what he saw as a lack of process for the determination of such a strategy. I remind the honourable member that a body within the Federal Government-that is, the Federal Cabinet-has a very important role in terms of an integrated strategy and particularly in terms of the very important liaison that would take place with such other departments as Foreign Affairs and Trade, along with other interested players, in determining what would be considered an integrated strategy.

Some of the other issues the honourable member raised with respect to management also need to be commented upon by way of looking at some of the larger projects that the Government has been involved in and the actual control of those projects. Each of those projects has a project director who is responsible for its overall guidance. There has been a project director for the submarine project. Commodore Peter Mitchell is in charge of the Anzac ship project. Overall responsibility rests with the Chief of the Defence Force, General Gration. The Secretary to the Department obviously has overall responsibility for the administration of the Department, and the important coordination role between the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and the Department is significant in that area. To be fair, the honourable member mentioned some of the significant progress that has been made by the Government in terms of rationalising, streamlining and making more effective the structures in management and the organisation in defence. That certainly suggests that there is a level of bipartisan support for some of the things that have been done.

The most obvious and recent action concerns the higher defence reorganisation resulting from what is generally known as the Sanderson report. The changes that are now taking place in the organisation of Defence Force headquarters and within the Department of Defence itself will obviously improve and streamline the whole process of doing what people would consider defence business. We believe that the job will be done better and, significantly, with fewer people. The overall thrust of the Sanderson report is that it is important that value be put back into rank so that the status of the senior officers who are carrying out those roles is enhanced. By the process identified in this higher defence reorganisation, we believe, the organisation will become more effective and efficient-by greater centralising of policy development, but decentralising the execution of that policy. That is very important for those people who are serving within the Australian Defence Force.

The obvious importance of the integration of the military and civilian streams to a great extent is very obvious. The staffing duplication that inevitably happens in large departments will be removed and we are looking at much flatter hierarchical structures which will certainly improve the general efficiency and organisation within the Department. The Sanderson report suggests that, while some of those important policy areas are being decentralised, we should certainly try to achieve a greater devolution of real authority and financial delegations and responsibilities to service management in the field. In the five months in which I have been Minister, senior officers have often said to me that they see their job being very much enhanced by their being able to perform what they would consider to be a much more meaningful and satisfying role in having a much better opportunity at the coalface of defence, so to speak, out in the field.

Another area I should comment upon, an area certainly directly within my ministerial responsibilities, is the issue of personnel which the honourable member for Mackellar raised. The Government can take a great deal of satisfaction, but not smugness, in its role in this area. I pay particular tribute to my predecessor in this area, who I believe did much to make sure that the general thrust in personnel management had a real impact for the men and women who serve our country. I would say to the honourable member for Mackellar that some of the important initiatives that were running prior to the tabling of the Cross report, Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force, in November last year were being addressed by this Government. We do not see my ministerial response to that statement on 11 May this year as some sort of finite point as far as personnel management and the whole question of addressing conditions of service are concerned. Obviously it is an ongoing thing. Most people would recognise this, but it should be pointed out that the Government did accept wholly, or in principle, 41 of the 48 recommendations of the report. A number of those initiatives are very much appreciated.

Later this month a review of service pay in accordance with structural efficiency principles is to be presented to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. I have talked about the review of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) fund being very important. Back in May I gave an iron-clad guarantee that no serving member of the ADF had any need to be concerned about that review because his or her conditions would not change, but quite clearly we need to question whether or not 20 years is an appropriate time for people to be eligible for the DFRDB scheme and whether or not some other aspects of the scheme need to be examined. I am delighted that Sir William Cole, a very distinguished public administration figure, has agreed to chair that review. I am sure that it will be very useful as well.

The renegotiation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and the great work being done by the Defence Housing Authority are very much appreciated by people in the Services and are having a real impact in addressing the question of morale that obviously figures from time to time. Let us face it: if we give people good accommodation we go a long way to having them think that, apart from the remunerative aspects of service within the Australian defence forces, there are other considerations. Obviously good quality housing is very important to families. This Government is spending $103m this year on defence housing, compared with an annual rolling average of about $35m a year during the Fraser Government's period. We are making an impact there and it is being appreciated.

I could comment on the question of personnel in relation to a whole range of other areas, but I will get back to the point raised by the honourable member for Mackellar about a supposed lack of personnel morale. His answer, which is to rely on better management systems, is not really the answer as far as this Government is concerned. We believe that it is a matter of giving the ADF clear direction and purpose. Obviously the White Paper, Kangaroo 89 and those sorts of activities give that sort of sense of direction and purpose.

It is also important that we as a nation and as a Parliament recognise the very valuable and significant role that the men and women who serve our country play in the defence of Australia. I have often likened it to a very significant insurance policy in the sense that when we shell out money each year for our housing insurance and motor vehicle insurance we hope that we do not have to use the policy for the purpose for which it is intended. The same could be true of the expenditure that the Government makes on defence. We need defensive preparedness. We need to recognise there is a very high cost in terms of government expenditure. I believe that it is money well spent and I am sure that most honourable members would share that view.

I turn now to the comments of the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles). I think that all members of this House-certainly those who have been in this Parliament over the last six years or so that I have had the privilege to serve-would recognise the honourable member's continuing commitment to and interest in the whole question of defence and foreign affairs. The honourable member mentioned his role on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and in the Caucus committee on foreign affairs and defence. The honourable member for Isaacs placed very important and well-deserved emphasis on Australian involvement in defence industries. It is a significant landmark as far as this Government is concerned that we have moved away from off-the-shelf overseas purchases of major defence items. That is good for this nation and for the Defence Force itself. Most significantly, it gives us a very significant economic and industrial base that can have spin-offs other than the obvious defence-related ones.

Mention was made of the submarine project and the Anzac ship project, and their obvious importance to the overall economy as well as their defence-related impact. The honourable member also mentioned the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar project. In that context it is worth while in this debate, since I am also the Minister responsible for defence science, to mention another area of my portfolio responsibility that is often overlooked, that is, the very significant contribution made by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO). Many people recognise that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation makes an important contribution to the nation, but often the impact and the contribution of DSTO are overlooked. Tonight I take the opportunity to pay tribute to the several thousand people who work in DSTO, who support the Department of Defence and who are at the cutting edge of defence technology and innovation. That needs to be put up in lights so that people can wave the flag about it from time to time.

Finally, I turn to the contribution by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor). His contribution focused largely upon the question of compensation and legal expenses in relation to the Voyager tragedy in 1964. I do not want to dwell upon this. I am not seeking to make a series of cheap political points with these comments. But I want to say this: from 1964 to 1972 and from 1975 to 1983 this country was governed by conservative governments. If it is fair to criticise this Government for alleged inaction and for not dealing with the problems of the particular person nominated by the honourable member for Groom, I think it is fair enough to look also at the action or lack of action by those people who were in government at that time. As the honourable member for Groom suggested, it is not an area that is being dealt with simply by the Department of Defence; it has other legal implications. In his contribution the honourable member mentioned the role of the Attorney-General. A debate like this, which deals with defence proposals for expenditure in this fiscal year, is not the opportunity to proceed too far on the question of compensation.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the three speakers for their contribution. We can be critical from time to time of some aspects of defence-management systems, morale questions and other challenges. But it is also a reflection of the general maturity of debate within this Parliament that in many respects the big policy questions in terms of defence preparedness and where we are going in a strategic sense are, in fact, bipartisan policies.
