TALK.START.PARA: —This Government does not give due credit to our rural industries as our major net export income earners. Recently, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) lauded the fact that tourism has now surpassed wool as Australia's number one export earner. He said that foreign exchange earnings from international tourism reached a record $6.5 billion in 1988-89, an increase of 17 per cent on the previous year. I join with the Minister in commending tourism on that tremendous achievement, because we need every export dollar we can get, and it is only tourism, primary industry and mining that are playing their roles for Australia. It is particularly sad to see the devastation of the tourist industry at present because of the ineptitude of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Minister did not say was that the $6.5 billion was the gross figure. Tourism is a two-way business. People leave Australia in large numbers just as, fortunately, they are coming to Australia in large numbers. The Australian Financial Review dated 29 August details this two-way expenditure as follows:

International tourists visiting Australia brought in about $4.5 billion worth of foreign exchange in 1987-88. But expenditure by Australians travelling abroad was estimated at $5.2 billion in the same period, according to the Industry Assistance Commission's recent assessment, Economic Implications Of Tourism Expansion.
This left the ``boom'' with a blow-out of $700m.

In the year 1988-89 to which the Minister was referring, the tourist industry earned a net positive figure of $430m. However, during the same year the net earnings from wool were $5.72 billion. This is because wool and sheepskins sold overseas earned $5.96 billion as against the $6.5 billion earned by tourism, but imports of raw wool, wool fibre, yarns, textiles and carpets during the year amounted to only $240m, as opposed to the $6.07 billion spent by Australians travelling abroad. The real net figure for wool would be even higher because there is a lower percentage of dollars repatriated overseas from the wool industry than from the tourist industry.

Despite this great and continuing achievement by the wool industry, this Government is more generous when it comes to recognising the export achievements of and providing assistance to industries other than primary industries. For example, during the last financial year the Government spent $46.4m to help with wool research and promotion to earn a net $5.72 billion in export income, and spent $42.3m on tourism, which had a net foreign exchange benefit of $430m. In addition, Australian woolgrowers spent $442.2m themselves on research and promotion and in support of the wool market.

Over the next few years, according to the Budget figures, the Commonwealth's contribution to tourism will be $38.76m in 1991 and $40.3m in 1992-93. On the other hand, assistance to the wool industry in those years will decrease to $26.46m and $26.3m respectively. This is because the Government is ending its assistance for wool promotion. At the moment it contributes $25m a year, which goes to the International Wool Secretariat to ensure the promotion of wool overseas. Incidentally, Australian woolgrowers provide about $200m a year for wool promotion overseas. The wool industry wants a firm commitment from this Government that it will honour the promises it has made over the years to maintain wool promotion. One has only to point to the fact that $25m is about half what the Government should be providing for wool promotion, and the industry needs this sort of forward commitment for its planning.

Not only is the Government cutting its assistance to rural industries, but also it is not helping those industries to reduce costs, particularly those applying to the waterfront and shipping. The wool industry is the largest container shipper in Australia and stands to gain most from waterfront reforms which this Government keeps putting off. Over the last seven years there have been four reviews and reports. The latest of those is the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA). There is to be an agreement, in principle, by the end of October of this year, and that agreement, whatever it is, is to be in force by July next year. So there is no hurry to reform the waterfront. While the Government is racing to take action against the pilots it is prepared to take years to do anything about the waterfront. This deal or fix, the so-called reform of the waterfront, will not necessarily help the wool industry, either, because there will be at least a $300m redundancy package for those affected, which the exporters of this country, significantly in this case the woolgrowers, will have to pay.

The Government has been even more negligent with regard to the live sheep trade. It is a major export industry for Australia-$250 to $300m a year-and exports to Saudi Arabia, which represented half this trade, have now ceased. Prices for sheep have halved in many areas because of the loss of this very important export industry. There is no sense of urgency or priority on the part of the Government to do something to resurrect and save this important export trade. We certainly need every export dollar we can get, with a projected trade deficit of $18.5 billion to $20 billion this year. No Minister is considering visiting Saudi Arabia or the Middle East. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not prepared to intervene. He washed his hands of any intervention or responsibility for this important trade in this Parliament last week. The Saudi Arabian government showed its contempt for Australia's Ministers when its Minister for Agriculture disappeared when a delegation of officers from Australia went to that country. Once again, I ask the senior Ministers of this Government to give this important export industry the priority it deserves.

There are two current issues of concern in relation to Canada and our trade with that country. The first concerns the United States-Canada free trade agreement, which commenced on 1 January, and its impact on our canned fruit industry. The second is the possibility of pork being imported from Canada. As the United States-Canada free trade agreement comes into force it is taking over, by the method in which it is being interpreted by those governments, from the Canada-Australia trade agreement. That has negative implications for a number of our export commodities, such as meat, sugar and particularly canned fruit. At $35m the Canadian market is the major market for our exports of canned deciduous fruit. That represents the livelihoods of about 1,000 people in the Goulburn, Murray and Murrumbidgee irrigation areas and the Riverland of South Australia.

Over a 10-year period, at 1 1/2 per cent a year, a tariff advantage encouraged a move away from Australia in favour of Californian fruit. I give credit to the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) and, on this occasion, the Prime Minister for being involved in representations with the Canadians, including the Prime Minister of Canada. They are awaiting a reply. However, the United States of America has now put forward a proposal to Canada to accelerate that transition period so that from 1 January next year the 10-year period would be compressed and there would be a 15 per cent tariff advantage for American fruit. With this increased threat and concern, I urge the Government to make a greater effort to protect this valuable export market for Australia. In addition, one should recognise the danger that these bilateral trade pacts, such as that between the United States and Canada and others around the world, are posing for access for Australian goods to those markets.

The second problem concerns the desire of the pig industry in Canada to export frozen pig meat to Australia. This is a subject of considerable concern to the industry for two reasons. First of all, there is the possibility that transmissible gastroenteritis will be introduced. Australia is one of the few countries free of that disease. Tests at the Australian Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong have shown that the disease can be transmitted, through frozen pork, to live pigs. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is to make a decision in the near future. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) will be recommending that minimal or acceptable risk be accepted by the industry. This recommendation should not be accepted. In the last few years atropic rhinitis has been introduced to the pig industry because of the laxity of our quarantine procedures. The industry wants an opportunity to discuss the old recommendations with the Minister before a final decision is made. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) indicated in the Senate yesterday that that would happen. It is very important that this be done. In conclusion, I believe that the AQIS policy of acceptable risk-we already have fire blight risk from New Zealand and a nashi pear scab and spot risk from Japan-is putting at risk one of the great natural advantages of Australian agriculture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in the debate on the appropriations of the Department of Primary Industry and Energy I would like to pay tribute to the emphasis that is now being placed on research and land and soil management, which is a welcome change in direction from the days of high subsidies and protection. Indeed, the changes in world prices put massive pressure on primary industries. Developments in other producing nations put additional competitive pressures on Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The existence of a corrupt international regime of subsidies and assistance, especially in the United States of America and the European Community, contributes to an unstable trading environment. This is not unique in the sugar industry.

These misfortunes are shared by all Australian agricultural industries. Wheat producers face similar difficulties, similar misfortunes. The same can be said for our meat and dairy producers. This, however, does not describe a disaster. Adjustment occurs rapidly in these industries. Through adjustment, new technologies are introduced, new enterprises are developed and new capacity is added. Through adjustment, changes are made in the structure of the family farm business, which guarantee its survival and ensure its prosperity. To not adjust, to not have the capacity to adopt the most efficient, low cost operation on farm and within industry defines a real disaster.

It remains the case that the sugar industry is rigidly and tightly controlled. This control acts to diminish the efforts and returns to dedicated and competent growers. It remains the case that there exist levels of interference, intervention and regulation which are unparalleled in any industry. It remains the case that it is the individuals-the producers and the sons and daughters of producers who make up the sugar industry- who are clearly disadvantaged by the current industry structure. But also, new players in the sugar game are also disadvantaged. The cost of entry remains extremely high.

It is simply not possible for this industry to ignore the developments in industry policy which have characterised the 1980s. The intensive efforts which this Government has made in negotiating a general decline in international agricultural protection have made the previous levels of domestic assistance unsustainable. It is now just not possible to speak with any authority in the international arena if, simultaneously, we indulge ourselves at home. Clearly, the win-win approach is an opening of our markets whilst maintaining the pressure for change in the world trading environment. We are just not going to win in our dispute with the United States if we are two-faced and inconsistent. The major trading powers will seize upon any excuse, any weakness and any delay in order to buttress their own flawed position.

I recognise that this is in stark contradiction to comments made just recently by the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Harper, who believes that the answer to the corruption of the international trading environment is to adopt policies just as distortionary and just as ineffective. Mr Harper advocates that we should jeopardise our efforts in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round and sacrifice investment projects in Thailand worth billions by closing the Australian market to imports of pineapples.

I do not underestimate the difficulty of achieving substantial reductions in levels of world agricultural protection. Thankfully, the benefits of unilaterally moving to lower rates of assistance are immense. By going it alone, by not waiting for other laggards in the protection game, we increase the competitiveness of our own industries, we expand the opportunities of our manufacturing sector and we increase the welfare of consumers.

The Government decided to reduce all high levels of industry protection. This, I emphasise, applied across the board and will benefit Australian primary producers by $2,400 a year. As I keep saying, there is no way that the sugar industry could have expected to see the maintenance of the administered pricing arrangements. I mention that in this we have received the full and welcome support of the National Farmers Federation. It realises that to engage in a program of subsidies, protection, bounties, marketing arrangements and pricing agreements is to indulge in a beggar-thyself process. This Government has moved to bring the sugar industry in line with other less well cosseted agricultural industries.

The Government lifted the import embargo, which had existed as a `temporary' measure since 1923. The administered domestic arrangements, which allowed for price discrimination between international and domestic prices, were similarly abolished. The removal of these measures has been accompanied by the introduction of a tariff at the flat rate of $115 per tonne, to be continuously reduced to $70 per tonne. The measure of protection afforded by this measure cannot be compared to that which exists for other Australian agricultural industries. For example, in wheat the effective rate of assistance is around 4 per cent, in wool about 2 per cent and in beef around 6 per cent. For sheep meat the figure is about 3 per cent. Even the rice industry is assisted at the comparatively low rate of 26 per cent. Yet these industries face corrupt markets where competitors are assisted by the full resources of national governments. Part of the reason why these industries have been able to exist, adapt and succeed in international markets is that the domestic industry structure favours rapid adjustment to the often rapid changes in the world situation.

This is not the case in the sugar industry. The current high prices which canegrowers are now enjoying and the strong expectation for continued high prices have given an opportunity, a precious opportunity, to change the industry. Now is the greatest opportunity we have had to change. More than at any time in the past, the domestic environment is now ripe for change.

The two key issues of interest must be, first, how can present industry arrangements be altered so that resources currently employed in industry are better utilised; and, secondly, what benefits are to be gained from industry expansion and an increased production and export of sugar? In other words, how can the present arrangements be altered so that the individual growers and millers will have the production capacity and industrial flexibility to respond more quickly to changing opportunities in the world market? The present arrangements restrict production growth. So, despite the desirability of increasing exports, that option is simply, and brutally, closed.

Considerable potential exists for the expansion of our industry. In fact estimates have been presented which suggest that a 50 per cent increase in production is achievable. This implies, using the price figures of 1988-89, an increase in export income of $520m. Given the current requirements for Australia to increase export income, it remains a disappointment to me that the expert producers of sugar are so comprehensively shackled in their efforts to trade their way to prosperity. I do not think I am being too provocative when I say that if this attitude prevailed in all sectors and in all industries, there would be no chance of Australia turning around the current account deficit. This is, thankfully, not the case.

Additional production would benefit not only growers but also those who are dependent on the income generated by sugar producers in Queensland. It is no surprise that the prosperity of our rural towns revolves around the successes of our rural industries. Thus, benefits would necessarily flow through from producers into the regional economies. This implies increased employment, increased income and increased opportunities for youth. Importantly, by expanding production, by fully utilising the resources which are available for full and proper exploitation, we act to secure the industry's future.

The ability of canegrowers to stay in the industry, the long term capacity of growers to resist the siren's call of land developers, white-shoe salesmen, smash and grab speculators and get-rich-quick sleaze vendors, depends on the resilience and dynamism of our own operations. By resisting change, this industry guarantees change. But it guarantees change in a way which, irresistibly, disadvantages those who are presently operating within the industry.

There is no doubt that individual producers have the ability and the inclination to increase production. New peaks and assignments have been taken up soon after their issue and then have been fully maintained. There is also no doubt that a substantial market exists for any additional increase in Australian exports. The Federal Government has done as much as is possible. The removal of the embargo was necessitated by the need for change as a catalyst which would force a re-examination of existing practices and policies. Further gains depend on movement by the State Government. This is, simply put, a real problem. The catatonic inability of the State Government to resolve its own pressing internal problems does not bode well for the development of proper industry policy. Indeed, I understand that some recent changes may make the situation worse.

Under the guise of streamlining administrative arrangements-a long overdue step-Mr Harper has moved to take hold of yet more of the decision-making process. This is an attitude of Mr Harper's which I find increasingly disturbing. He has made it clear that he believes that ministerial responsibility means that he personally decides who will receive what benefits from Government programs or who will pay the cost of the administration of regulations. Ministers should set policies, programs, priorities and guidelines. They should review the efficiency of the implementation and effectiveness of these results but they should leave the administration to the public servants who should be held to account. Failure to do this is a recipe for policy chaos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in the committee stage debate of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 which allocates $408,377,000 to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and associated areas dealing directly with primary industry. The difficulty I have with this debate is the perception we leave with the community that the Government is tonight earmarking $408,377,000 for the purpose of primary industries across Australia. The impression that the Government has left is that this is the measure of its concern for farmers, growers, viticulturists and all sorts of intensive primary industries around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that in this Budget and in this committee stage debate we have to recognise that there are areas of Government allocations that flow to rural industries that are not a part of this specific Department of Primary Industries and Energy allocation. Take, for example the Department of Social Security allocation; take, for example, the money made available for roads. All of those funds, in part, flow to assist Australia's primary industries.

Tonight I want to say that we should not in this committee stage consideration of the Appropriation Bill be sold on the idea that this money will go solely to benefit farmers. The reality is that this is not a lump of money being made available to Australia's primary producers; this is a lump of money being made available to encourage the very industries we need to address our balance of payments deficit. If we run through the Budget Papers and look at the total allocation of funds to farmers-the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) suggesting that a figure of $1.3 billion has been earmarked by the Government for the purpose of encouraging primary industries around Australia-we should not see that amount as a sum of money being made available to farmers. Of that $1.3 billion, rural industries of their own volition contribute, it has been estimated, $882.9m because of what they pay through levies, taxes and charges.

Tonight we are dealing with the industries that have the capacity-the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) has alluded to this in his address-to address part of the disastrous balance of payments deficit from which the nation currently suffers. These are principally export industries. Even some of the smaller primary industries, even some of the labour intensive primary industries, even some of the horticultural primary industries are now finding that they are in demand in export markets. There is great opportunity for the Government to do something about having a more productive nation by fostering the industries that the member for Hinkler has referred to and industries such as the cut flower industry, the fruit growing industry, the viticultural industry and the vegetable industry, particularly into the Asian market.

The Government simply cannot expect the farmers of Australia to commend it for its Budget surplus while the nation continues to go broke. I have used an analogy, as the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) who is at the table will be aware, in my Appropriation Bill speech, but I will not bore her by repeating it tonight. I want to make the point that farmers who rely on productivity to keep them in surplus are saying to the Government that this lesson in productivity is the same lesson the Government must learn in budgeting terms. A surplus in the Government's own Budget means very little in turning around the productivity of the nation. That is as far as I will go with that farm analogy in the time that is available to me.

Farmers continue to be burdened by what has been the blunt tool of interest rates in that every time they seek to expand, every time they seek to borrow money, they are discouraged from doing so because of the Government's present interest rates policy. Inflation has been a further burden under which Australia's primary producers and exporters are forced to labour. I want to take up the point made by the honourable member for Hinkler and say that neither the farmers nor the Department of Primary Industries and Energy expect to be supported by the Government. They simply expect to have unreasonable burdens removed. The honourable member for Hinkler ran through a litany of effective rates of protection currently being enjoyed by primary industries relative to those being enjoyed by secondary industries. I support his remarks that the primary producers that he and I represent have nothing to apologise for in that area.

In this Budget allocation farmers expect to be treated fairly, not favoured. On that note I refer to one particular farming industry that I think has been treated fairly-some will say it has been favoured but that would be quite unfair-and in its fair treatment, highlight what has been the inequitable treatment of another primary industry. In the Budget Papers-I did not have time to run through this point in my Appropriation Bill speech-the Government moved to change the taxation rate on flavoured milk. Whereas previously a milk product had to have 95 per cent milk in it in order to attract the favoured 10 per cent tax rate, now that level of milk product can fall to 90 per cent and it will still attract the favoured 10 per cent of sales tax.

If the Government is to be consistent in its approach to primary industries-perhaps, Mr Chairman, you would pardon me if I were to take the milk analogy one step further, and say that if the Government were to be homogenised-it has to ask: Why are we prepared to take this decision regarding flavoured milk and treat fairly-not assist-the dairy industry but not do precisely the same thing in the case of 100 per cent fruit juice? If we have a 100 per cent fruit juice product we have a commodity which is nothing more than that fruit wrapped in a carton. Let me use orange juice as a good illustration. If we have a product that is 100 per cent orange juice, it is effectively a food. But that product is currently taxed as if it were nothing more than a beverage. I will just plead to the Government for a little--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you don't eat it.

—The Minister insists on interjecting by saying that we do not eat orange juice. That is a valid but superficial interjection. May I say that we do not eat milk either. But that product does not attract a sales tax. I am pleading for a little effort from the Government to be homogenised in the way in which it deals with what are effectively food beverages. I think, entirely properly, the Government is determined to change the tax structure on flavoured milk. To be consistent it should do the same thing for fruit juice. I simply plead with the Government in this committee stage of the Appropriation Bill for that measure of consistency in its approach to what is a primary industry with the capacity to earn further export income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak in the committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 tonight. Firstly, I would like to focus my remarks on the coal industry and in particular those fields in my own electorate of Oxley. The recent announcement by the discredited National Party Government in Queensland on the cutting of rail freight rates for coalmines is long overdue. However, it only goes half way as the new rates will only apply to new mines and big expansions to existing mines. What about the existing mines? They just miss out. Understandably the local coal industry is upset at this half-baked decision, for even members of the National Party in Queensland should realise that it would give new mines a competitive edge.

SPEECH.PARA: Another recent problem for the west Moreton coalfields has been the granting of a sole contract by the Queensland Government to the Ebenezer open-cut mine to supply coal to the Swanbank power station, the largest domestic contract in the district. This open-cut mine was purchased by a Japanese company, Idemitsu, last year. At the time of the granting of this licence by the Queensland Coal Board, it was understood that coal from this mine would be sold on the export market only and the company would not enter the domestic market. However, we now see this large domestic contract go to the Ebenezer mine although the coal from this mine comes from a different seam from that currently used by the Swanbank power station. The power station was designed to take coal from the known Bundamba seam. The letting of this contract to the Ebenezer mine should therefore mean that expensive alterations will need to be done to the power station. The granting of this contract to the Ebenezer mine will see the loss of jobs in the labour intensive underground mines which have previously supplied the coal to the power station, and especially so with the Rhondda Collieries Pty Ltd mines. Once the Queensland Government realised that it had come up with the wrong decision, did it then attempt to rectify things? Not a chance. Similar to the rail freight decision, we see another backflip that only went halfway, for we now find that the Queensland Government has advised the Ebenezer coal mine that it will be excluded from any future domestic contracts.

I call on the Queensland Government to exclude the Ebenezer mine from all domestic contracts, including the one it has just granted, and to recall the tenders for this contract at the Swanbank power station. Mine owners and unions together accept marketplace realities, but the commercial domination of open-cut mines has led to fears that the underground mining will be phased out, naturally at the cost of many jobs. The Queensland Government, instead of offering assistance to existing mines with reduced freight charges, goes out of its way to put fear into the industry by allowing the running down of one section of the industry against another. With the loss of the Swanbank contract, the Rhondda underground coalmine has no buyers for its coal when that contract runs out. This is despite the reports of an anticipated increase in demand for steaming coal from Japan. The exploitation of cheaper open-cut coal has jeopardised at least 100 million tonnes of west Moreton reserves. The State Government has ignored every call to ensure that contracts were evenly divided between open-cut and underground mines; it has seen fit to ignore the calls of the unions and the mine owners.

What the Federal Government must learn to do, and what in fact we are doing with other industries and trying to do with the coal industry, is minimise the adverse impacts of fluctuations. The first thing to do is to make sure that as many as possible of the producers at the margin are as competitive as possible and able to withstand downswings. There will always be downswings and we must learn to accommodate them and not try to ignore them. The answer lies in a very strong industry involvement in the information development and assessment process-that means unions, companies and governments together.

The 1989-90 Federal Budget also saw an increase of funding for land care and rural research. Funding for soil conservation has been increased to $23.4m for 1989-90, which is more than the $10.6m spent in the 1988-89 year. This money will go to some 400 projects across Australia directed towards achieving sustainable utilisation of our soil and land resources in line with the recently released national soil conservation strategy. In 1988, the Australian Soil Conservation Council adopted a proposal to declare 1990 the year of land care, and to declare 1990-1999 a decade of land care. The year and decade of land care are a joint Federal-State exercise with the active support of the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation.

Major items of expenditure will include public awareness, participation and education campaigns to build community awareness, and action on soil conservation. In 1985 this Government undertook to match dollar for dollar industry contributions to joint rural research schemes up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of each rural industry. Nineteen rural industries are covered by these arrangements and the Government funding to match industry levies will increase by $15m to $80.4m for the 1989-90 year. To further our understanding of the geology and prospects of finding petroleum in the offshore basins around Australia, the Government funds the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics continental margins program. Funding in 1989-90 will be $14m.

Total outlays by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for 1989-90 will be $1,406m, as against $1,335m in the 1988-89 year. This includes $775m, an increase of some $7m over the 1988-89 year, from levies on industry to fund research, marketing and promotion schemes. This more than shows that this Government is committed to the rural sector. We have in the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) a very capable and competent Minister. He is well respected and highly regarded throughout the industries he represents. The people in those industries know that they will always get a fair hearing from this good Minister. A total of $10m will be allocated for the national afforestation program in 1988-90-double last year's expenditure. This will maintain the stimulus the program has created in hardwood establishment and encourage research into increasing the viability of plantations.

The Government provides direct financial assistance to the agricultural, forestry and fishing industries primarily in the forms of price support, rural adjustment and disease eradication schemes, quarantine and inspection services, and contributions to research and promotion. It also provides cost recovered services for the sector, including the exercise of compulsory taxing powers to collect levies on behalf of rural industries. The aim is to foster more efficient, productive, innovative and adaptable primary industries, remove constraints on Australia's export performance, and improve Australia's international competitiveness.

One other area I wish to comment on is the funding of electronic transfer of export documentation, better known as EXDOC. The decision made in this area will provide the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service with additional resources of $2m in 1989-90 for the implementation of EXDOC. This expenditure will be fully recovered by charges on industry. Both the meat industry and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation have been closely consulted during the development of this secure and efficient system. The direct benefit to exporters-initially meat-includes no longer having to physically lodge documents for each export consignment, more rapid validation of documentation, and the consequent earlier release of payments for the consignments. Other commodities falling under the control of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service will be phased into the EXDOC arrangements over a period. Under the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Act 1988, the Commonwealth provides funds and services to enable farmers to overcome financial difficulties arising from circumstances beyond their control-to improve their performance by changing the size of their farms, improve managerial and financial skills, adopt better practices and technology and, after all options have been considered, allow those farmers without prospects in the rural industry to make an orderly exit.

This Government currently conducts a number of energy management programs both in its own right and in concert with the State and Northern Territory governments. In the government sector the range of training courses on energy efficiency and post-training materials and services will be expanded. A data base of government energy use will be developed and a monitoring and reporting system established. In the transport sector, activities to promote vehicle fuel efficiency projects will be expanded. The Government's programs will also target the residential sector where actions to reduce high levels of electricity use could have considerable beneficial impact on greenhouse gas emissions. The Commonwealth will join the States in a range of promotional activities to encourage improved household energy use. Information will be provided to local governments on the potential for improved domestic energy efficiency through the administration of building and planning by-laws. Energy efficient housing design, both in public and private housing, will be promoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any day one looks at the newspapers, one sees some story about Lebanon. The story is not about the Lebanon that used to exist years ago with its capital Beirut the financial centre of a prosperous part of the world; the story that we read these days is one of suffering, tragedy and desolation. Largely that is brought about by the Syrian forces in Lebanon whose aim seems to be no less than the destruction of Lebanon and the destruction of Beirut itself. That is an extreme charge because it amounts to something close to genocide; yet it is a charge made by no less a person than the Pope himself. In the Australian Financial Review of Thursday, 17 August, a report states that, referring to the Pope:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the latest shelling of Beirut was an attempt at ``genocide'', and compared the Syrians to ``Cain who made himself culpable for the death of his brother''.
It is also reported that the Pope said:
In the name of God, I appeal to the Syrian authorities, asking them to cease the bombings that aim at destroying the capital of Lebanon and the entire country.

Is that not the truth? Do we not know that that is what is taking place? Yet so little is done. So little diplomatic international energy seems to be given to this truly disastrous problem. If one picks up the International Herald Tribune of a few days ago one will see on the front page a photograph of an exodus from Beirut travelling south. It is one of the worst looking traffic jams one could ever see. Cars are 10 abreast. Those people are fleeing for their lives from a city that is being destroyed around their ears.

The Syrian Army has around 40,000 men in Lebanon. It occupies two-thirds or more of Lebanon. It seems determined, under President Assad, to drive other forces out of Lebanon and to dismember that country. The dream of greater Syria has not disappeared. The dream of greater Syria is there. What do we do for the Lebanese people? We do very little. God knows it is a difficult problem. There is no easy answer, but can we not do more? Can the countries of the world not do more than they have so far? Recently-and again this was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 17 August-the Secretary-General to the United Nations convened a meeting of the Security Council. The report states:

A declaration, adopted unanimously by the 15 members said: ``The Council . . . urgently appeals to all the parties to put an immediate end to all operations and to all firing and shelling on land and sea.''

The truth is that nothing has happened. The truth is that destruction continues, shelling continues, and loss of life continues. The demolition of the city of Beirut and the lives of its people continue. What I hope the Government will do, as part of its international diplomatic efforts, is give high priority to some coordinated action to bring pressure on Syria to get out-to bring pressure on the other parties, the other foreign forces in Lebanon, to get out. It needs a program of constructive diplomacy. If the superpowers can agree on the resolution that was agreed to in the Security Council they may even agree to work together with the other major powers to put some pressure on Syria to get out in the name of decency-for the lives of the Lebanese people and give them an opportunity to reconstruct their country. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since this is the first time I have spoken since you took the chair, Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your high achievement.
—Thank you.

—The attempt under way to form a solidarity-based government in Poland marks the first attempt at a peaceful transition from a communist regime to one with a non-communist leadership and substantial political pluralism. While non-communist authoritarian systems have made the transition to democracy, there is no precedent for what seems to be under way in Poland. As Lech Walesa said recently, `Nobody has previously taken the road that leads from socialism to capitalism'. The Polish developments are important for Australia because of their intrinsic significance and because Australia has direct interests in East-West security. The next Polish government faces a severe economic situation, with high inflation, low output, outdated manufacturing plant and an exhausted and alienated work force. A Solidarity-led government must try to cope with these problems and simultaneously set up a new structure of political authority. The solidarity movement will clearly face substantial internal strains as well, as it moves from a repressed opposition force to be a leading force in government.

SPEECH.PARA: The political and economic problems facing a Solidarity-led government indicate that there is no room for complacency in the West about prospects for change in Poland. Gorbachev's courageous and audacious policies in Soviet domestic and foreign affairs have created a window of opportunity for peaceful change in Eastern Europe which Poland and Hungary in particular are seeking to use. Change in Eastern Europe, however, needs to be well conducted and effectively implemented; otherwise it will not be lasting. It is clearly in the interests of Western states to support the process of reforming Poland and to give Solidarity a chance to achieve success in its economic reforms. Aid and support must clearly be given in a cautious manner so that it is not seen to be aiming at compromising Soviet interests and not bringing into question Poland's membership of the Warsaw Pact alliance. This point was made recently by a senior American analyst, Brzezinski. What is needed from the West is a combination of material support and rhetorical restraint.

There are several ways the West can help. Poland clearly needs substantial amounts of capital to make it possible and feasible for the economy to revive. There are critical shortages of both consumer goods and capital equipment. The West can help substantially by acting to alleviate this capital shortfall. There are grounds for concern that so far some major Western countries are not responding to the pace of change in events in Poland and to the critical need to support moves towards pluralism and democracy in a concrete and not just a rhetorical way. So far the United States of America has committed just $119m in aid to Poland, which is one-fifth of the cost of one Stealth bomber.

The European Community and other interested Western states could organise programs to allow a substantial number of Poles to gain skills in running economic enterprises. Western countries could encourage the process of economic reform and recovery by providing wider access to Polish goods. It is clearly anomalous that exports from East Germany freely enter the European Community through the Federal Republic while Poland's exports cannot.

The West did not create the problems of postwar Poland, but it is very much in the interests of Western countries to support those who are fighting peacefully, valiantly and intelligently for political and economic renewal in Poland. At a time of economic stringency this issue, none the less, deserves Australia's interest and support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I, like the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), acknowledge that this is the first time I have spoken before you and I congratulate you on your appointment. Furthermore, it needs to be considered against the drop of around 30 per cent in real terms over the last 6 1/2 years. SPEECH.PARA: Under this Government, the principle of user pays is as hollow as the Budget we have just had presented to us. This year they will pay out an estimated $5,645m in excise tax, and they will not be amused to know that, of that amount, around $4,300m will go elsewhere rather than on road funding. This Government has become very professional at robbing Peter to pay Paul and the Australian fuel user and road user has had enough. He or she recognises this Budget for its hypocrisy in this regard. In the townships which are not connected by bitumen in my electorate-and there are plenty of them-I am sure that the users would find sufficient materials on this issue to tar and feather the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

Has any honourable member on the other side of the chamber been required to send children by bus over 40 or 60 kilometres of rough and dangerous dirt roads-roads that become impassable in the wet? What does that do for family life?

TALK.START.PARA: —Life is tough in the bush.
—It is indeed. It is a good thing for the rest of us that those who live there stay there.
—Have you ever been there?

—I certainly have; I have lived there all my life. How effective can a schooling system be with this type of difficulty to be overcome? The Treasurer would not be able to comprehend the impact of this lack of provision on families, farmers, travellers and operators of small businesses in rural communities. In places such as Pilliga and Burren Junction-little towns in isolated areas-the reality for many people is no bitumen for many kilometres. Those communities have paid their way in more ways than merely the fuel excise tax, and they deserve better. Good roads mean better productivity, lower accident rates, less damage to machinery and equipment, and faster delivery of produce to marketplaces and export destinations.

SPEECH.PARA: Any business manager would know that, if one neglects part of a business, that neglect will cause the rest to suffer. I submit that this Government's neglect of roads will contribute to its downfall. The coalition is committed to a substantial increase in road funding. We are listening to the concerns of the motorists and road user organisations, whom this Government has regarded as milking cows for too long. Over the last six weeks or so I have visited every township in my electorate. I can say with absolute confidence that the condition of roads is uppermost in the minds of most of these people there. They have had enough. We have an urgent requirement to address their needs in this area because the prosperity of the nation depends upon their having the wherewithal to give of their best. Labor will not give it to them; the coalition must.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself compelled to comment that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), who spoke before me, comes from the outer suburbs of Sydney, yet he complained about roads. The reality is that, if he wanted to do something rational about improving roads in this country, he would be advocating that we put a lot of money into rail. I believe that there is room for at least $1 billion worth of expenditure to upgrade rail services in this country. In this way we would be serving some useful purposes. We would be making a rational decision to carry long haul freight on rail, where it is most efficiently carried, and taking off the roads the heavy trucks which do the damage to the roads. The honourable member talked about people paying. The reality is that heavy trucks do not pay; they cost. The Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport in Western Australia showed that heavy haulage costs far more than is recouped in the way of taxes and charges. So if the honourable member wanted to do something serious about roads he would strongly support the modernisation and unification of the rail system. If honourable members opposite were to have any policy at all that is the policy they should have. That is something they could berate this Government with. I do not believe that we as a government are doing enough in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish you would stop honourable members opposite inciting me on the adjournment. I find myself continually getting sidetracked from what I want to talk about. Tonight I want to talk about something which I have mentioned before.
—I ask the honourable member for Adelaide to stop inciting the honourable member for Kalgoorlie.

—Mr Speaker, I thank you for your protection. This adjournment debate gives me an opportunity to talk about the slaughter house for sacred cows. I believe that a lot of sacred cows deserve to be slaughtered. The particular sacred cow that I want to deal with tonight is the concept of the level playing field. Mr Speaker, it would have been much more convenient if you had not been prompted.
—I will not have any reflections on the Chair.

—It was not meant as such. The only people who play on level playing fields are good losers. I think we ought to recognise that it is not the way industry performs anywhere in the world. If we have good and successful industries we should be giving them all the support we can, not trying to make the playing field level.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are serious about our overseas earnings we must look first at adding value to our natural resources. Herein lies the greatest opportunity to get improvements. I think the Western Australian Government leads the way. It leads the way in adding value to gold and wool. It is desperately trying to get mineral sands off the ground against the strong objection of the environmentalists, or, as I prefer to call them and as they are more accurately called, the prohibitionists. There is nothing in Australia to equal the Western Australian timber trust concept at the moment in the area of forest products.

This brings me to the criminal actions of the Victorian Government. I have just spent some time at Orbost and I must say that I am appalled at the Victorian Government allowing 100 tonnes per hectare of usable timber to lie and rot or be burnt on the forest floor. It stays there as half-burnt logs and debris. I am told that that material amounts to about 1 1/2 million tonnes. In woodchips alone it is worth $100m to us in income, but a lot of that timber is actually millable timber. It could be milled and only the residue, the waste material, put to woodchips.

The Victorian Government seems paralysed in its actions because down there the environmentalists-these prohibitionists-say, `If we allow woodchipping we will need to get a pulp mill, and if we get a pulp mill political pressure will continue the practice of forestry'. Forestry has a proud history; forestry is an industry that deserves to continue; and forestry, through forest products, is one way in which we can address this nation's $1.7 billion deficit. It is a national disgrace.

In conclusion, I applaud the stand of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who has told those silly National Party people in Victoria that the future lies in the development of the industry. Those people are resisting the development of the industry to protect their own selfish, short term interests. They are frightened that, if we get timber workers there, they will probably take over the local government. Would that not be a shame! It is in Australia's national interest that we should be ensuring that this timber is used, that we are addressing our current account deficit problem, and that jobs are created. I believe that the Victorian Government ought to get a very strong message from the more responsible Ministers in this Government such as the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that that is the way to go.

Pty Ltd of North Adelaide and Gilbert Street. They are international designers in Tokyo and London and throughout Australia. They have supported this marvellous charity since its inception.

One of my favourite ladies, who has been a great support to me, is Phyllis Southgate of Impulse Promotions, a marvellous and creative talent. In 1984 I was invited to come down from Blyth in the mid-north of South Australia for the primary producers executive committee to write, produce and play in a revue called On the Sheep's Back-A Jubilant Revue. It was here that we linked together a very exciting concept of theatre and fashion which played very successfully in South Australia in 1986 for the Jubilee 150. Phyllis and I have stage-managed many fashion awards and fashion parades together. This was her final parade. She is hanging up the glitter and turning off the spotlight on charity functions, including the Lady Mayoress's fashion parades.

I continue with the rag trade theme. I refer to a great enterprising company within the electorate of Adelaide called Saville Row Pty Ltd. Neville and Patrine Quist are the principals of Saville Row. This international fashion house has huge export potential which is being realised in the United States of America and Europe. The fashion manufacturing, supply, retailing and employment industry is alive and well in Adelaide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sport has always been an important part of the Australian way of life. This is particularly so in the City of Ipswich, on which my electorate of Oxley is based. This city has a long history of producing many sports stars of both national and international standard in a wide variety of sports, including all the major codes of football. Ipswich has had such high representation in international competition that it has its own international club.

SPEECH.PARA: However, when we think of sports people, we do not always think of the administrators behind the scenes. Tonight I would like to speak about a man who made a lifetime commitment to rugby league. The contribution of that man to ruby league will be sadly missed in Queensland rugby league circles, particularly in Ipswich. That man is John Clark better known as Gov. Gov passed away on 10 June this year at the age of 74 after suffering heart failure following surgery. His involvement with rugby league spanned 59 years, from a fourth grade junior player with the premiership local side through to senior administrative positions. Gov Clark's dedication to rugby league was all-consuming and his long involvement with the game, particularly at the local level, has made his name synonymous with the Ipswich league.

As I mentioned, his involvement with the game commenced 59 years ago in 1930 as a fourth grade player with the local premier side. The next year he played half-back for the side which was then known as Starlights, and in 1934 became team captain for Norths. His playing career was interrupted by a four-year stint in the Army when he served in North Queensland at Townsville and Thursday Island. In 1965, Gov became secretary of the Ipswich Rugby League, a position he held for 16 years. During this time he fought long and hard in the interests of Ipswich Rugby League. He had very firm views on the future of the game he loved so much and was not afraid to take on anyone who would try to sway him in those views. This strong commitment often brought him into conflict with his good friend the late Ron McAuliffe, who was a former boss of the Queensland Rugby League. Many honourable members will remember Ron as a member of the Australian Parliament, representing Queensland in the Senate for many years.

Gov continued his administrative role as president of the Ipswich Rugby League for three years and as Queensland Rugby League, Ipswich and West Moreton branch chairman of directors for three years. His role extended nationally as the Queensland delegate to the Australian Rugby League for three years and as a proxy delegate for 10 years. In 1972 he co-managed the Australian World Cup side which toured England and France and attended an international rugby league conference in Paris during the same year. His dedication to the game was recognised when Ron McAuliffe awarded him life membership of the Queensland Rugby League. I understand that he also received the British Empire Medal about six years ago.

Gov Clark's role as an administrator in the local league has no doubt contributed to the production of so many great rugby league players from the Ipswich region, many of whom are still making their impact on the State, national and international competition. His efforts for the game he loved will not be forgotten. His memory will linger in the minds of present and future players and administrators in rugby league circles.

In addition to Gov's great contribution to rugby league, he was also a keen Australian Labor Party supporter. He was always proud to display a Labor sign in his front yard during election campaigns. He will certainly be remembered in my local area as a great rugby league supporter, worker and player for many years. I offer my condolences to his family.

I have had the opportunity to speak to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, which is easy to contact at 132 Albert Road, South Melbourne. Its phone number is in the book. I was amazed when it was indicated to me that no politicians had bothered to ring up to get a point of view. The pilots recognise, as I said in my press release, that a 30 per cent pay increase is obscene, is difficult to comprehend and is always going to be challenged. The pilots are a group of professional dedicated men who have always said that this dispute was tacky. Their claim has always been open for negotiation.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to statements which have been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in challenging the stick time hours. A roster shows that the flight time for a Boeing 767 for the month in question was 62.7 hours. For the A320 roster, the flight time-again referred to by the Prime Minister as the stick time-was 61.68 hours per month.

Tonight the pilots have issued a press release saying that they are prepared to work from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. I believe that the olive branch that has been held out to the employers has been rejected. Ansett Airlines of Australia has said that it will not negotiate. I guess that its guidelines are that one cannot really go back to work and still be on strike.

This country is haemorrhaging and the tourism industry is suffering. Both parties to the dispute have thrust and counterthrust across the table. I plead with the politicians to ring the pilots to see whether something can be achieved. Surely, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) or the Prime Minister can pick up a phone and dial into Melbourne.
